reviews.review: Oldest area in Rome.. Centro Storico is where ancient Rome is... markets, food, shops and delis, restaurants, the heart of the city.
My favourite area. My favourite area of Rome: great to strikke along the narrow streets and come upon small squares, old churches and fine noble palaces
Without words!. It is beautiful beyond words. There is something for everyone, and in a day you can choose to visit different monuments in different styles.

Rome Central. Just take your time to take in all the architecture, it is beautiful. We had time to sit back and take in the views, so would meander off and look at the different buildings and walkways, then return to see more that we had missed.
NICE WALKING. The centro Storico of Rome is very rich; from Roman Times, Medieval Times and Pre Roman Times. Nice to walhk arround an explore!

Wow . The beautiful Rome gives you a special value in life. Our visit to capitol and the old Rome takes the breaths out of you. Go there, use time and see the beautiful rests from our important history. Take your time, walk slow and let the history hit you and all your senses.
wonderful!. what can you say about Rome? is just wonderful! everywhere you go, every step you make, you see pure beauty, charged with history and art!

Unbelievable!. So many antiquities in a walling distance. The historical center is a small region which you have to walk to enjoy!
Only negative the thousands of tourists - like you - everywhere.

Second time around it was a relaxing yet historically interesting experience. Loved just sauntering about the old streets and spotted all the sights with no haste or queuing. The first time was a bit different, more hectic and lots more queuing.

Without doubt a great area to explore. Full of wonderful buildings, piazzas and cobbled streets this is one of the best areas we have visited. There is a striking view round every corner, you can wander for hours. The piazzas are full of fantastic statutes or fountains for you to admire. One tip the piazza cafés are quite expensive, wander off te beaten track and you will find traditional and more reasonably priced alternatives.

Gorgeous part of the city. This is the absolutely best place to be for a first visit to Rome since it's near all the sites. You can stroll the cobblestone streets with friends and have fun or your significant other and feel romantic during the day or night and it even feels safe. Lots of tourist trap type restaurants however but you can always uber to another area of the city if you want fine dining or better food.
Picturesque,lively and walkable.. Loved just walking around,in comfortable shoes, and stumbling upon Rome. Ancient and beautiful. You can walk much further than you think.
Evening walk. Centro Storico is a great place to take a walk in the evening, enjoy the Piazza's, fountains and architecture. There are many restaurants to choose from. Would recommend a warn evening.

diverted by domes. Central Rome has so many churches, there is almost one every block, that i sincerely recommend pausing and briefly looking inside every one whenever you see that they are open; you will be so glad you did. The huge diversity and richness especially in the interiors has to be seen to be believed. Collectively, the sum is far, far greater than the mere addition of the parts, and I am describing an aesthetic not a religious experience.
Amazing place !. The historic center of Rome is one of the most beautiful achievement of mankind. The only little drawback is that it is way to busy.

Eternal city. This is an eternal city for sure and just strolling around in the historic centre is amazing. Old buildings and even older buildings, restaurants and shops. Just walking in Rome is an amazing time.

Best Collection of historical Buildings on the Planet. Where does one start? You turn a corner and you're faced with a building that forces you to say "wow" - even if you're a cynical 62 year old like me!Some of the buildings would be the main attraction if they were in another city but don't even warrant a mention in most Rome guide books.Don't think for one minute that you can see all the major sights in one day - you can't!

wonderful. you have to see this, brilliant, there is so much to see and do, dont know where to start really, but soak it up its so wonderful, all the buildings the history, just to be there is breath taking

An experience around every corner. Its important to make sure you read the history or you can very easily miss most or the history. So many Palazzo s belonging to the old families of Rome with some still home to decedents. Many are not accessible but tour can be arranged and you'll see the grand lifestyle these families led

Three places you must visit: Piazza Farnese, Piazza Navona and the Pantheon. Start at Piazza Farnese where you can have a coffee at the only bar on the Piazza, then follow the signs for Piazza Navona (just across the main street called Corso Vittorio Emanuele) but don't stop at any of the restaurants here as in my view they are not good value for money. Once you have admired the Bernini fountain follow the signs for the Pantheon which is a sight to behold. Again the bars/restaurants around here will charge higher prices because of the location, so I would not recommend them, but try the ice-cream place which is few yards away from the Pantheon and which boasts 150 ice-cream flavours, can't remember the name of the place or the address (sorry) but if you have the Pantheon on your right (passed the two bars facing it) take a left and walk around 100 yards and you'll find it.

City with soul. If you want to experience Rome, see his stunning monuments and explore his side streets you should take your time. I visited Rome in the summer- it was pretty hot but I enjoyed movement in the streets, buildings including stunning churches and monuments, many lovely fountains, and Italian language.

Rome is simply stunning. Do not even think about taking a cab or bus while visiting Rome. The historic center is best accessible walking. Be prepared for a long walk, though.
Every step discovers beautiful, historical buildings, piazzas and the wonderful atmosphere of the Eternal City of Rome.
Amazing. Really Beautiful, a throw back to the history of Rome, really well kept and interesting, worth seeing

Beautiful neighborhood to stroll and watch. The entire historic center of Rome is charming, architecturally interesting, and great for people watching. Do your best to avoid the tourist trap pizzerias, restaurants, and cafes. The best way to do this is (1) don't go anywhere with menus in 10 languages and (2) don't go anywhere that has someone standing out front calling people inside. With so much to check out, just walking around makes it a great afternoon.

Huge but yet bless feeling. It is a must to visit and spend time there how details the architecture and so beautiful. Amazing site! A bit teary when I enter the centro although not in the centre of the area. Follow the volunteer where they pointing so you don't get shock when they approach you not to take picture. There few location and angle where you are not allow to take any pics in the Centro. Feeling great and bless to be there.
Family visit.. we stayed very close to here. went to mass in the church, very peaceful inside, a contrast to the outside which is a hive of activity. would recommend.

heart of old Rome. If by Centro Storico we are talking about the general centre of the town, the old, historic part, then of course this is the best part! Just stroll around, in and out of the cobbled alleys, stumble across numerous piazzas, drink coffee (or even better, prosecco!) and people watch - that's what Rome is all about.
Bring good walking shooes. Just walk around and enjoy.Every Basilica and Church are worth peeking into.Enjoy a pizza for lunch in one of the many Pizzarias.

Just beautiful. Its a good way and place to spend some time with very beautiful architecture. The square in front of the buildings has an amazing fountain called Quattro Fiumi (4 rivers). No entry fee!
Enjoy old Rome. We never get tired of the old center of Rome. Go around and look at all the old old houses and pillars or sit with your coffee and look at people and traffic. Enjoy.
Must see. Amazing experience, must see in your life time, i felt like back in time to the famous Roman empire.

How much time do you have? It won't be enough. The World Heritage folks say that the area encompasses everything inside the (17th century) walls, as well as St. Paul's basilica (outside the walls). That's pretty much all of old Rome.The centro storico (historic center) must have:(1) monuments of antiquity (2) fortifications built over the centuries (3) Baroque and Renaissance urban developments (4) civil and religious buildingsThat's pretty much all of "Rome" (and it is all of Rome, in the eyes of the World Heritage Organization). Some Centro Storico highlights are:the Colosseum, the Pantheon the city walls and Castel Sant’Angelothe Piazza Navona the Piazza del Popolothe Piazza di Spagna)the Spanish Stepsthe Capitoline Hill the ForumTrajan’s Column the Column of Marcus AureliusThat's just a start; the basilicas and churches will fill pages. Rome oozes with "Historic Character" and the World Historic Organization has recognized that. After spending several days in Rome, I have come to the conclusion that a good, long week (or more) would really be needed to scratch the surface of the Centro Storico (Historic Center) which is actually all of "Rome".

Worth every step. What a gorgeous gorgeous and historical place to visit. Loved it. To be able to sit on the steps looking back towards where you approach this spectacular building was a true reward, worth every step taken to get there. If you choose, pay a few euros to walk around more exhibits. If there were more hours in the day; would have done this. What a gem.

Something to see with every step. Daytime or evening, so many things to see that you really cannot take it all in. Historical buildings everywhere, wonderful small shops, cozy small restaurants, gelaterias... You could spend a day just walking around and being surrounded by the wonderful atmosphere.

Don't bother, should not be in the top 30 attractions. Waste of time if you have limited time in Rome. Maybe I mis-understand what Centro Storico is supposed to be By using the Trip advisor location I ended up on a plaza with one statue, neither are noteworthy. Not worth the walk or the time,

Huge interest but terrible pollution.. The historic centre is of world importance, but the authorities must deal with abominable traffic. London has tried very hard, but Rome is far behind. Pollution is a real problem; I suffered the adverse results; and historic buildings are also suffering. Private cars rule Rome.

Great place to enjoy evening walk. There is no other place like centro storico of Rome.with hundreds of moniuments avey step you walk. It is safe so walking at night is not a problem. Do not miss Trastevere for authentic Roman cuisine

The Best Place to be in Rome. Just walking through this historic center of Rome is an experience in itself. Small alleys will lead you to incredible restaurants and unexpected historic monuments/buildings.
Stunning!. It's so breath taking to be able to stand in historic locations like this and admire the work done by people to build these buildings, statues and streets.
Breathtaking monuments and easy to access. Everything is so close-by and exploring this fantastic city by foot is just a wonderful thing that you should have done at least once in your life!.

Not to be missed.. We came across this amazing building while looking for the Spanish steps and went back the following day to investigate. Went at opening time so no crowds, walked around the exterior and also paid to see the military museum which was a great insight into Italy's turbulent past.Something not to miss is the exterior lift ride to the roof, only €2 I think, one of the highest vantage points in Rome and what a view!
Beautiful . I loved Rome and loved this building. Just impressive. Can't even describe it and pictures don't do it justice. We stayed in Rome three days which just wasn't enough.
Impressive . Impressive building, one of our favourite. All around is beautiful, we were lucky it was not crowded and we could enjoy all j side as well. Perfect

One of the bests!. We walked a lot, but it was worth it! Our first time in Rome was exhausted of course, but as the most travellers say, this is the best way to explore a new city! Don't hesitate to enter every open door you find!
On your way to Pantheon.... It is a wonderful artistic building, it is free to go insinde but at the top there is a museum which you should buy a ticket to visit.
What sculptures and views. Incredible. You wonder how all these structures were made, how long did it take. Everywhere you look something else to see, Just walk and enjoy theres nothing more to say!!

Incredible city. It's difficult to say which of the main attractions are the best, some of the magic is also seen simply by walking the old town. It's an absolutely incredible city that I love to revisit!

BUSY PLACE. This is the place where everything of interest to Tourists take place, from Cafes to shops to sites of historical value.A must for all tourists, it can be very crowded.Be aware of "PICKPOCKETS" & "CONARTISTS"

Heart of Rome. As a tourist, this area is where you'll spend most of your time. You can wander, take in the sights, explore, shop, pick up tasty treats, and more. No matter which way you walk, you'll make fun discoveries.
Olde world charm. Great for piazza ,s street acts restaurants it is vibrant and chic with its fabulous fountains churches works of art and narrow cobbled streets . Wish I was there now .

Centro Storico Rome. Rome my wonderful Rome is full of history and its magnific monumental traces. It is on outside wide opened museum and history. God is giving not history only but also tastty yammy Italian food and fashion.

History! Live!. Rome, the historical centre, is an amazing adventure. Scottish by birth but living in Canada for more than forty years I was proud of the history of Scotland but to live and walk around central Rome is to immerse oneself in the origins of civilization. Take the time to go somewhere slowly. Wander around the next corner and you will probably find yet another small local bar/cafe where you can relax. I miss it already!.

"Magnificent Rome". If you are interested in history and art then Rome is the place. It is amazing what was made by Romans 1000s years back. One can see beautiful palaces, churches, ruins fountains and sculptures. The cobbled streets of Rome are full of restaurants and cafes. Worth seeing even if you are not fond of history.
Beautiful Rome. Every structure in Rome is so magnificent. Makes you realize how powerful we humans 1000s of years ago. And also realize that we may have regressed...
Magnificient and Dazzling. Centro Storico of Rome is magnificient and dazzling! The buildings, the light, the sculptures. It will be amazing to enjoy with a little less people and tourists.
Beautiful Rome. All the historical centre of Rome is important and impressive. The palaces, the churches and the ruins are incredible. Walking along the streets is a wonderful activity itself.

Wonderful area to wander around. The heart of Rome, featuring cobbled streets, many shops, galleries, restaurants and cafes. The beautiful Pantheon, glorious Piazza Navona as well as other smaller, pictureque piazzas. Wander around for hours and don't worry about getting lost, this only means more surprise discoveries around every corner.

Magic. I was here with my two young children and it was a marvellous experience. Just walking, looking into the shop windows, enjoying gelato and enjoying the spectacular beauties at every corner was a truly magical experience.

Unique in the world.. If you are interessted in history and art there is no better place in the world. If you are not interested in history and art centro storico will still be worth a visit beacause its so unique in the world. Recommended for almost everyone

One amazing place after another. For tourists looking to be in the cuore (heart) of it all, the best place to be in Rome is in the centro storico. Indeed, the historic center of the city is where a chunk of the Eternal City's main attractions are located. The best part is that most of it can be covered on foot. From taking that postcard perfect photo in front of the immense Pantheon to enjoying the lovely street café scene at Piazza Navona, the centro storico has it all!

One amazing place after another. For tourists looking to be in the cuore (heart) of it all, the best place to be in Rome is in the centro storico. Indeed, the historic center of the city is where a chunk of the Eternal City's main attractions are located. The best part is that most of it can be covered on foot. From taking that postcard perfect photo in front of the immense Pantheon to enjoying the lovely street café scene at Piazza Navona, the centro storico has it all!

THE HAPPENING PLACE!. Piazza Navona is the heartbeat of Rome, The Happening Place, the Pulsebeat...There is always something going on here.This is the centerpiece of Centro Historico and has cafes, ristorantes, small shops and locals as well as tourists lounging about. Marvel at the incredible fountains by Bernini.. Grab a latte, a cold beer or a light meal and then wander off into the local neighborhood to see the many palazzos, and beautiful churches containing numerous works of the masters (Caravaggio, Borromini, Raphael). Take your time and feel the wonderment of this place.

A lovely visit, very refreshing. This place was easily one of the most happening places I saw in Rome. Great energy about it. There are some lovely cafes. There are two beautiful fountains. There is a lovely building, an Obelisk and street performers who keep the fun going. The best part is you can sit down and relax on the ground and see the things just unfold. Wonderful and a definite to-go place if in Rome.

Magical Heart of Rome. I've seen lots of definitions about what defines the Centro Storico, but for me it simply means the historic city center bounded by the Tiber on the east and perhaps Via dei Serpenti on the West. Maybe the Forum is the southern boundry, maybe not. What's important is that it includes so many amazing places to explore. If you have time, throw away your map and just wander. Around every corner will be something else that will make you happy. Many of Rome's bucket list sites are here, but don't forget to just slow down and just enjoy Centro Storico's vibe.
Excellent.. Centro Storico is a must see, but this area is very very crowded like all centres of major cities. Just go with the flow and enjoy what you see.

Piazza Venezia and surroundings. Given the contents of the reviews and the photos, the Centro Storico seems to refer to the whole central area of Rome that is basically the whole Rome, making the rating the attraction almost like rating Rome itself. I will concentrate the review on the pedestrian area starting from Piazza Venezia, looking at the Altare Della Patria and going all the way to the Colosseum, passing through the Trajan column and other Roman ruins. It's a delightful walk, especially if you add the multimedia presentation at Palazzo Valentino, where you will get and explanation of the meaning of the carvings on the Trajan column, and enjoy the view on top of the Altare della Patria. Budget 2 or 3 hours for this walk, more if you watch the multimedia presentation.

I love it. I loved sitting around sunset time looking on lazy hazes reflecting on centro storico's windows.In front of the building, some street artists perform nice shows, I loved the fire playing-man show.

An open air museum - lively with music and history. We recommend that you attend 1 one the light shows, they bring rome to life and you enjoy and appreciate the surrounding , stones and reminiscent building structures. In the evening street artist and musician give extra flavour to the boulevard

An Open Sky Museum!. Nothing can be better than roaming around in Rome. It is a spectacular city! Everywhere you look, you will find something historic and unique. I loved walking around Rome, and felt that 3 days just wasn't enough to truly soak in the flavours of this ancient city. We walked from the Spanish Steps to Trevi Fountain to the Pantheon to Piazza Navona and more. It was amazing!

The beating heart of Rome. While there are specific attractions here that you may want to visit, a lot of the charm of this area comes from the fact that you can just wander the little streets (not so little, however, that cars won't be there - so be on the lookout) without any particular plan. Allow yourself to get lost, admire and inhale the aromas from the various food shops, do a little window (or real) shopping, and just savor the atmosphere. This is our favorite part of Rome.

You love it or you hate it. To me, Rome polarises people. It's air of decay tends to put some off, whilst others simply love it. Rome's historical centre has a magic about it and a sense of romance not found in many other European cities, to the degree found here. So much to see around every corner.

The most beautiful town in the world. What do you search for?Fountains? Nowadays, there are about one hundred from Renaissance to XX Century, passing through Baroque and XIX CenturyChurches? There are about one thousand from early Christian to XX Century. The 7 Basils are the most important ones.Museums? There are more than 1 hundred about Art, Science, Technology, Literature, History, Music.Rome Empire? Here we are

Explore Amazing Rome!. Rome an amazing city to wander around - ancient history and a story around every corner! We spent 5 nights in the city and just about managed to visit all the main attractions... This particular area of Rome (historic center) is no exception to the rest of the city - attractions, restaurants on every street, spend a day or two here soaking in everything it has to offer!
Not to be missed!. We stayed near the Vatican so were lucky to be able to pass this area everyday. In my opinion, the nicest area in Rome...

Excellent city to roam in. . Rome has some excellent attractions including The Vatican City, St. Peters Church, The Pantheon, Piazza Navona, The Colosseum, Roman Forum, many museums and other major churches. Also many great small eateries selling pizza etc. The metro is fairly good service and covers the majority of the city.

Bella Roma!. Walk the city or use one of the hop-on-hop-off buses to explore this magical city. I always walk with my head looking up because I just can't get enough of all the terraces on top of the old buildings.

Just wander. Rome is a beautiful city full of character. This is a great area to just walk around and get lost. Plenty of restaurants, stores and great buildings to look around and the people is so welcoming. We just love Rome.

The heart of the Roman Empire. How long you spend here depends on how much time you have in Rome. It would be easy to spend a week just pottering round area taking in the detail, trying to separate the different and overlapping building periods and styles of buildings. Even looking at the pediments of many of the existing shops and offices in the area and the street pattern - all Roman. But do not miss the son et lumiere shows at night in the Imperial Forum and Caeasar's Forum. They brings those parts to life.

When in Rome you have to be here. Rome is one of the most beautiful cities in the world, there are always a lot of tourist specially in the summer time, I have to say I prefered Rome in December than in July (too hot in July), but I had a great time with my family visiting all the nice places the city offer and enjoying the delicious Italian cuisine
what can I say?. This is Rome, full of excitement, good food, overflowing with history and magnificent architecture. Traffic is horrendous, but we knew that going in

Must see. Beautiful Roma especially during the Christmas period or in spring.
Roma is one of my favorite cities

Amazing historical place. If you visit Rome, then this is a must go. Its greatness comes within the local streets, sites and houses. Full of restautants, at your own pick, depending weather you want a local pizza or an international cuisine. Very hospitable people !
Roma. You can walk on every little street in the historic centre and you may find beautiful places and interesting buildings or museums at every corner.

heart of Rome. In the Centro Storico,you cannot rush for a visit .First there is the Vatican which takes quite a while to full visit after a long waiting line, then you have via della Conciliazione full of souvenirs stores and don't buy at the first one mingle a bit first

Enjoy Rome, the walking city, as it was meant to be enjoyed. Centro Storico shows why Rome is such a great walking city. After it was built in days before mass rapid transportation systems. So here you have within a short walking distance of each other many historic sites. If you venture from Via dei Corso towards the Piazza Navona, you will see a lot of winding narrow cobblestone alleys where it is easy to get lost - but in no other city will you enjoy being lost like this! Wonderful trattorias and pasticcerias abound! Well lit in the evenings, it makes for a great romantic stroll (if for the gaggle of tourists everywhere).

Best to wander without destination!!. Could spend years exploring the central historic area of Rome. Too much to describe and list. Great to simply wander the narrow streets and see where they take you....churches, fountains, monuments, piazzas,

Quintessential Rome. When people conjure up an image of Rome this area tends to be what they imagine. Lovely historic area with loads of famous sights and buildings. Great place to stroll, marvel at just how much history and character can be squeaked into one area and grab a coffee while watching Romans go about their frantic daily lives. Beautiful romantic and absolutely a must.

Best place for a romantic stroll. As I lived there, there is nothing like wandering, getting lost and find your way in a place like centro storico. Definitely a place to go, recommended by the sunset especially.

The Historic Centre!. When in Rome! However don't need to tell you to go here. Over 2000 years of marvellous art, buildings and churches. What more to say, apart from being able to get fantastic ice cream and food! Any visit to Rome will ALWAYS lead you to the centro storico.... otherwise you are not alive!

Walk through history. The unique centro storico of Rome is the ideal place to wander without a map or a destination. You will come upon lively and colorful street markets, fountains, sculptures, Majestic Roman buildings, historic churches, wonderful street cafes and bars, the best gelato in Rome, a vibrant living city. Cobblestone streets, street performers, surprising sites around each corner. Charming restaurants with outdoor seating. Do not be afriad to just spend the day wandering the streets and experiencing the best of the Roan la dolce vita.

Excellent Visit. This area is definitely worth a visit. Everywhere you turn there are beautiful and historic things to see, would recommend a visit to the Pantheon and Sant'Ignazio which is a Jesuti Church with lovely sculpture of trees inside (see my photos). Lots of little alleys and streets. Also visit Rome's most famous square, Piazza Navona.
Great location. We stayed in this area of Rome and was able to walk to so many areas quite easily. It is surrounded by so much architecture, history and eateries. I would choose to stay here again.
Wonder Place. Part of a larger area which is just brilliant. The condition of it is excellent and it is very well presented. Plenty to do in the area and some good restaurants as well.

Just stunning. Roma's historic centre is one of the most beautiful city centres in the world. It is fully of places to see and wonderful buildings to admire. It is worth spending a couple of days there

To maximize your stay in Rome, position yourself in a perfect location.. The eternal city is certainly where I eternally want to return to. While in Rome, we stay at the "Hotel Regno", located on the Via del Corso. What a gem. The operators of the hotel are wonderful in every respect. The rooms can vary in size, but in every room I've had, they were wonderful. There is a cozy restaurant in house that is perfect for breakfast and planning you day's explorations. The Regno is located just two minutes walk, through narrow restaurant laden corridors from the Pantheon, Piazza Navona, Spanish steps and the Trevi Fountain. The colosseum and Vatican city are within walking distance and the sights to be seen are spectacular. You should not be disappointed in considering this pleasant setting, whether it's your first or repeat visit to the "eternal city".

This is the reason you go to Rome.. This part of the city is like a movie. Every corner holds another piazza, beautiful buildings, tiny streets, fountains and so much more. The only way to truly see everything is to just walk....alot. It's amazing. I would recommend a tour on your first day so you can get to know some of the history to go with the landmarks. You can try one of the free walking tours which we have done in other countries. Then you can go back later when you have a little lay of the land and visit the ones you're most interested in. One other tip is to also see them at night. They look beautiful all lit up. Last tip is to make sure you stay in the city. All of the chain hotels are on the outskirts. Use Air BNB or VRBO and get a house or apartment. That way you can come and go as you please each day. Do not drive. I'm from Boston and I thought our drivers were crazy. They are insane. If you stay inside the city everything is within walking distance. No need for public transportation at all.
The Eternal City. Without a doubt the most wonderful city I have ever visited. So much unbelievable art, history and architecture to see. Just breathtaking.
Amazing. wonderful place to explore- so much history to see and explore. they say that Rome is an outdoor museum-I agree. everywhere there is a historical building or structure.
Excellent!. I like my trip in Italy, it was very beautiful, more informations and more places very beautiful!trust to try it by your self!

The heart of Rome is really something unique!. Coming from a country with numerous ancient landmarks, museums etc I wasn't sure what to expect from Rome. Needless to say that I was taken aback!The city centre is a masterpiece, the dream of every tourist who wants to walk around and absorb the atmosphere of a trully unique city - it combines almost everything you can ask for in terms of sightseeing: from nice parks to amazing churches and from unique works of art to trully spectacular architecture.It's not just art though. The city has a nice vibe that makes even walking around it an experience. What not to like? The food is NOT great, mind you, despite what the numerous guides tell you. The pizza is nice, the gelato is even better but you really need to look around in order to find something trully special.

The Ancient city centre still standing. The Centro Storico is where you'll find some of the oldest, still standing pieces of Ancient Rome. The Pantheon, Piazza Navona and masses of churches and other wonderful buildings from various periods of history - each and every place offering to inform your understanding of the development of the modern world. Whilst Rome is a great place to shop, in my opinion it's not for shopping or boasting that you should come to Rome. Come to Rome to wonder at how much like us the 'ancient' Romans were, to discover the history of European art and architecture (both everyday and religious) and how to enjoy living in a very crowded city! You can still eat well reasonably, sightseeing doesn't have to cost a fortune and you can rest in the cool of largely empty churches when it just gets too much. I am not sure that the Centro Storico is the best place for young children but bright youngsters of 11+ who aren't only interested in technology and TV should enjoy themselves, especially if they have intelligent parents who recognise when a little leavening is needed!
walk, gaze, stop, look, walk. wonderful city, so much the same over the decades, so changing. Great food, busy streets, friendly taxi drivers, crowds of tourists, so much to see
Fabulous. Well worth visiting, beautiful architecture. Loved every minute. We were surprised there weren't many people there. It was about lunch time when we made our visit

Historic Center is the Place to Be. The Centro Storico, or Historic Center, encompasses the city center where many great sights are located such as the Pantheon, the Piazza Navona, Campo de Fiore, Largo Argentina, and much more. It's a great place to walk around. The tiny lanes give off the essence of Rome. There are plenty of shops and restaurants.
Stunning architecture. What an amazing piece of architecture, steeped in history. Rome is just full of beauty everywhere you look.

Enjoyable to walk ariund. You can get a very satisfactory experience of Rome just walking around in the historic centre. We travelled with small children and didn't feel like queuing up in all the major culture sites but chose to spend much time both during the day and at night wandering around in the historic centre and it was a bliss.Shops are in plenty and the variety of high quality goods are vast. Opening hours are also generous which makes it possible to shop both early and late.The children loved it!

If you're going to Rome you're going here.. Centro Storico or "historic center" is the center of just about every Italian town. This is why you're a tourist here, so get out, walk, get an appropriate number of days Metro pass (try to avoid rush hour). There are pick pockets on the trains - a girl of about 10 tried to get our empty water bottles from our backpack. There is so much to see, pace yourself, realize you can't see everything. Stay hydrated. Almost everyone is helpful. Near the major tourist attractions there are people there to help you find your group, the right line, etc. I thought they were scammers, but we were never once steered suspiciously.

must visit. Rome is one of the richest cities with regards history and architecture. To my surprise I found it to be cleaner then most other cities. The best way to see Rome is on foot so not to miss anything.

Unmissable!. I love Rome! It is wonderful! Rome is a museum! Wherever you walk, you find places to go, always surprising, churches, monuments, COLUMNS, buildings, surprise and delight you. Some people complained of Rome and I do not understand why because it's gorgeous. The truth is that they have't visited this year, but it really is clean and well maintained, I did not find trash or graffiti on buildings. The cleaning cars on the streets often aspired trash.

History around every cornrr. This area is a big part of what makes Rome so special, and so different from other European cities we have visited. The layers of antiquity, the knowledge that there is probably treasure beneath your feet, the sight, around every corner, of buildings or ruins that date back thousands of years--it's just magical. It's chaotic, messy, and perfect.

One of the most beautiful cities in the world!. Rome is really one of the most beautiful cities in the world, especially the historic downtown! Just make to book everything way in advance because all attractions and hotels go fast!
Amazing centre of the eternal city. Quite generic to say 'centro storico' but of course I assume it recall all the walking area around the roman ruins, stunning in particular at night

A must do. My wife and I always look for Hotels or appartments in the centro storico area whenever we visit Rome. In order to be in the middle of so much architechtecture be it the Piazza's the Churches, the monuments and museums you wish to visit as well as all the shops and stores

The best!. One of the most beautiful city centers in the world! It is like an enormous museum. Wherever you go you can see amazing structures, squares, fountains and sculptures. Everyone remembers the first time he saw Fontana di Trevi coming out of a corner!
Fab by night. Wandering around the centro storio by night is amazing with the Roman forum and collesum lit up. Fab location to stay. Lots to do all within walking distance.

The place to be!. I'd never been to Rome before and was not disappointed by all there is to see and do, The lovely little narrow streets, filled with shops and restaurants and surrounded by such incredible sites!

Fun morning with a plaza full of artists, vendors, musicians, levitators?. Clearly a popular hangout. Families, teens, artists, musicians, kooks, acrobats. Kind of reminded me of Fanueil Hall area in Boston, just a great place to kill some time people-watching.

Walk and admire!. Walking around this part of Rome is vibrant with citizens and tourists alike coming and going. The city is clean and the gelato and store fronts are very welcoming. You will feel safe as a tourist as we did as the police and military are blended into the congested areas where people congregate. We visited the first and second week of May 2016 and could not ask for better weather. The international Gelato festival,Italian Tennis Open and other events were going on while we were there. Great time to go!
Lovely architecture. A beautiful part of Rome, which includes may historical buildings, boutiques and restaurants. You should watch out for 'tourist traps', which fill the streets.

Everything in Walking Distance. We have been in Rome for 3 days now and are staying in Centro Storico. Everything is in walking distance. A leisurely stroll to the Ancient Part, lots of restaurants, shops and sights. So much to see and so little time !!!

Magnificent. We hadn't been to Rome since the 1960's......Europe on $5 Day!!!!!!Frankly, we didn't know WHAT to expect. Even with ALL the visitors.....Rome is a definitely WOW.We rented an ap't for 5 nights on Via Giulia......and EVERYWHERE we wandered there was something of interest: history,architecture,churches.,restarurants,piazzas,etc,etc,etc.Now my hidden agenda is returning to Rome.....renting an ap't....and spending a month or two wandering and enjoying.

Just Rome with all good and bad things. You can find good and bad restaurants, problems with transport, some pickpockets, unclean roads but all this is hidden when you walk from fountain to fountain from Roman ruins to Baroque churches and when you feel the life in Trastevere and eat ice cream near Piazza d’ Espagna. Rome can be even better when you visit the city with your love or very close friend. Try to do so but not during hot summer. Rome is nice even in October and November.

Fabulous - but so crowded. I have been to Rome before, but each time its so different. As you turn each corner, or walk along a side or a back street, all of a sudden you see this amazing piece of history. Breath taking and humbling. How many churches...so many but you never get bored of entering the next one. It's hard to take it all in.....One tip, June is "tourist" month - if you can skip it and go another time. We won't visit again in June.
Wonderful. Every corner you turn, or so it seems, there is another amazing historical building to marvel at. We were especially lucky as the weather was perfect.
A MUST-SEE AND DO!. Central Rome is truly amazing and the shops and restaurants and architecture are all overwhelming and must see and do attractions.
MUST. you can t go to rome and random in the center of rome. All the art of Renessance is there... so once again open your eyes and feel the energy
Great Square. it is a must see. A very old buildings and churches which are still in a good condition and tells you history. Exciting tour.

wow wow wow this place one of the best hotels. The staff the views are all amazing out of this world.. wow wow wow this place one of the best hotels. The staff the views are all amazing out of this world. amazing

Plenty to see, could take several days to really explore. Lots of history, shops, places to eat, winding streets with surprises around every corner. Take the time to explore this area after seeing the big sites in Rome and enjoy.

Cheap and complete. A man who is tired of Rome is a poor soul. Rome needs much care at the moment ( Streets, monuments, public transport, etc) but it remains one of the best cities in the world, full of history and cultural events. You really don't know where to look first: roofs and cupolas?, gardens and palaces?, columns and ruins?, shops and cafes?. Rome always offers a treasure to its visitors

Love Rome. Centro Storico is wonderful to visit afoot, there is so much to see you can spend here several days and still keep discovering. We found it always crowded with tourists, some streets so full of people you could not even walk. But there is no place so charming we've seen since!

small and crowded. The centre of Rome is beautiful, but it is not that much bigger than the centre of other cities. What is different is that it is incredibly crowded, and rather neglected. Besides the tourists, there is all that come with them... sellers, of everything, everywhere, and way too many "Italian" food shops. All this seem to have been left to grow organically, with the only welcome exception near the Coliseum where there was no food outlet in sight - planned? If so, well done!

Historical Centre of Rome. This area runs from Piazza deal Popolo to Piaza Venezia along the Via del Corso.You will find Piazza Di Spagna ( Spanish Steps ) and the Trevi Fountain here.This is the main shopping area with all the designer shops located in the Via Condotti and the Via Frattina.Lovely to stroll through here on a warm summer nightAll the side streets have hidden treasures Lovely cafes and gelato shops to stop at for a quick treat

Heart of Ancient Rome. Well worth your while to walk this are if you are able. Some highlights: Campo de. Fiori, Palazzo Spada, Piazza Navona and Fountains, Pantheon, Chiesa di San't Ignazio di Loyola among others. You can create your own walking itinerary from travel guides, but "when in Rome" this is a must , to get the best idea of "ancient " Rome. Also , encourage you to get a capuccino , gelato on the way or window shop. Highly recommended.

There is something in every lane !!!. What a place. Rome is such a fascinating city and their city centre is perfect. Every street has something to see. Just get lost in the narrow streets and you will have a great time.
Delightful despite the crowds. Try to wander round as early as possible in the day especially if you are going to the Piazza di Spagna.

Beautiful city. We walked around the old city center for hours. In every corner you can find an historic monument, museum, etc. Everywhere you walk you can find a good pizza, ice-cream, or any type of good Italian restaurants.

5 stars will never be enough for the heart of Rome. There isn't a number high enough to rate Rome's historic center. Beauty, art, history, and amazing food is around every corner and found in every tiny winding street. An eternity is not long enough to spend in the Eternal City.

Lots of walking wear good shoes. Walking the historical center of Rome is great fun, history at every turn. The tourist spots are crowded and awful but take 10 steps away, go up an alley, and you find the real heart of Rome. There are cafes tucked away and street theatre to watch. An Ape (look it up) overloaded struggling up a hill. People living their lives in this ancient city. Yes there are monuments to see and churches to visit, but don't miss the best of the alleys. Escape the selfi sticks for a little wander.

Stroll and savour. The historic centre of Rome is fantastic to just stroll around, so atmospheric with history from so many eras at every turn. Allow half a day to cover the main sights. Gets very crowded during the day (keep an eye on your bag and pockets) - insanely so at the main sights (Trevi Fountain was the worst) but almost deserted in the evening after dark. Entrancing and quite unlike any other European capital. Next time I visit I will join a tour though, just to find the highlights, then go back and savour again at my leisure.
Nice Place. The place is very nice. Our hotel was very close from this place and we often wold and spend time in this area.

You CAN do Rome in one day (even though I don't know why anyone would). It's smaller (psychologically) than Paris. I mean, just get out your map and use a highlighter to mark, in this order, Termini, Barberini, the Spanish Steps, the Trevi Fountain, St. Andrew's Church, the Pantheon, Piazza Navona, St. Angelo's Castle, St. Peter's, the Sisto Bridge, Trastevere, the Fernese Palace, the Piazza di Venezia, Trajan's Forum, the Coliseum, Monti - you're done. It's a six-hour walk. Anything you catch in between is a plus. I wouldn't do this, but some people claim to be exceptionally busy. What with the crisis and all. Maybe there wouldn't be a crisis if they weren't so busy. Never mind.Listen: it's a great city. Really. Seriously. Honest. You'll enjoy it. All of it. It's nothing like New York, and only a little bit like Paris. It's older than both of those combined. Overall, it's probably more beautiful than both of them combined, and, hey, I'm a New Yorker. If you really, really want to enjoy it, you've got to slow down. Stay as long as you possibly can. A week is nice, two weeks A LOT better, three weeks better still. I daresay the folks at home can manage without you in the interim. You may be important, but not THAT important. Kick back and relax. Have some chianti and some coffee, enjoy that pasta dish. The veal and the chicken are amazing, yo. Look at all those stone pines.
Great place for a stroll. When we arrived they were dismantling scaffolding from a concert, but still got some great pictures, very historic and worth a visit.
Easy walking. It was actually really easy to walk around and fairly small so it was good for not getting too lost.

Memories of a great empire!. Rome was one of the greatest empires in the history of mankind and there is so much left over, despite the disintegration of the empire that you need many days, perhaps weeks to visit even the most important parts of historical Rome. Fortunately, some of the important areas to visit are clustered together: the Roman Forum, with the Colosseum and the Teatro Marcello will keep you busy and entertained for days. The Vatican is of equal historical (and political) importance. Rome is full of palaces, art galleries, historical buildings and views to deserve one week for your first visit and much more later. For those interested in art, don't miss the Galleria Borghese, the National Museum of Rome, the Vatican Museums and the Galleria Pamphilj. For those more inclined to view and admire Italian fashion, via del Corso and via del Babuino are important starting points. For Catholics and Christians in general, the Vatican has immense attraction. For those intereste din architecture and medieval and reneasissance art, Rome has a wealth of churches, starting by the St. peter cathedral, San Giovanni in Laterano and hundreds of others. For those interested in food, Rome has more restaurants than most other cities around the world and expresses a variety of cuisines. An don't forget the best coffee in the world...

Centro Storico Fantastico. If you haven't spent a good deal of time in Rome's historic Center you haven't really visited Rome. The atmosphere is unbeatable in all the walking streets. Great shopping, eating, incredible historic gems around every corner. There are loads of tourists but just turn another corner and escape the hordes or sit in an outside cafe and ogle the incredible mix of global visitors. It's also a great place to stay and soak it all in.
rome is always magnificent.. The charm of the Center is just wonderful. Lots things to see. Wonderfull to walk, although always crowded. but still incredible and worthwhile to see. Never give up
History all around - amazing area. Wow what an amazing part of Rome. so much to see and do. Just wander the streets and enjoy the fantastic sights!

Wherever You Tuen there is History. Just wander down any street and you will run into history. You just have to walk around and even without a map you will stumble on amazing sites , churches, fountains or historic sites. Just go for a walk and soak it all in. There is also plenty of shopping you can do along the way as well as eat and drink.

Never-ending pleasure. The historic center of Rome, enclosed within the Aurelian and papal defensing walls, is an amazing site with more than twenty-five thousands points of social and archeological interest. Rome is the city with more monuments than any other city in the world, but in the same time this is the lively and exciting place to enjoy every second of your visit.
Enjoy, wander and wonder. Around every corner is something magnificent, stunning and worthy of time to reflect, enjoy and simply admire. Take a decent amount of time get the most out of your visit.

Endless pleasure. Actually, one can spend all his/her time in Rome just walking through the historic center of Rome and this would be a smart choice :-) Endless attractions, great food, Roman life - that's real pleasure!

Fifty-five years since my first visit and I'm still going back. I arrived as a grad student in 1961 and fell in love with Romans. That hasn't dimmed during repeated visits and our honeymoon. Changes include fewer noisy scooters, men urinating indoors instead of against walls along streets, and almost no feral cats now. There is a joy here that ancient and modern barbarians can't dim. Architecture: all you want but look at how each millennium builds on ruins of older. Food: stick to traditional dishes that locals eat. Distances: tiny. Most attractions aren't more than 15 or 20 minutes from where you stand. Costs: dirt cheap to beyond my imagination.

Vaticano. The tour was organized by I LOVE ROME TOURS , the guide 'Giuseppe De Spirito" was aware of every detail, he was perfect with describing everything in details, he replied all the questions of the group, he was very helpful and decent, i would join more tours with him in the future
What a sight!. This building just comes out of nowhere and it is amazing how massive and amazing it is to look at .

Art, food and shopping. The centro storico is an amazing place to visit.You can only walk around some places without visiting the museums, there are great shops and restaurants and while walking you can see the main sites.Don't miss Trevi Fountain and Spanish steps.

Fantastic. No words to describe it. It's amazing. The narrow streets, boutiques, cafes, restaurants, piazzas, old buildings.... It feels like you are in a fairytale. It's very easy to go around by foot as the centro storico is quite compact. I just love it and I'm sure you will too

La dolce vita. On our first trip to Italy, we stayed in a hotel. Since then, we return once or twice a year and rent an apartment in the Centro Storico. You can see 75% or more of the top places in Rome on foot from this location. An apartment allows you to take advantage of the wonderful markets and create something at home which adds to the feeling of living like a local.

Walking in central Rome- a feast for your eyes!. One of the things I love about Rome is that just walking around the center is such a pleasant experience. There is so much beautiful architecture everywhere you look...the small winding streets, the fountains, old buildings..it is all beautiful. When walking from one place to another you can discover so many things you would have otherwise missed had you taken public transportation instead. I would recommend staying in central Rome and walking everywhere (if possible) to get the most out of your visit.
It's HUGE!. I was surprised at how large this facility was! The view from the top of the stairs out over the City was lovely! And it's not a far walk to Treva Fountain from here.

Beautiful Piazza - became our landmark when lost in Rome. Our trip could have been titled 'Lost in Rome' because each day their was a period during which we would become lost wandering through the narrow streets and stumbling upon little piazza's and hidden shops - but each time we somehow found a view of the fabulous white building which looked down over Rome and it became the landmark which guided us back to the center from which we could get our bearings and start our discoveries all over again or wearily make our way back to our hotel. We spent six days wandering round and found new things every day - I am sure this area has more than enough sites/shops/restaurants etc. to cater for tastes - I dare anyone to go to this area in Rome and not be impressed!
Walk on!. Beautiful part of Rome, it is always enjoyable walking through it and every time you pass, there is something new you will spot, detail, building, architecture.
A must-see in Rome. Obviously you cannot come to Rome without checking this out, so much history everywhere you look. Well worth getting some guidance so that you can take in the meaning of it all.
Go for a wander!. Rome is the kind of place that you can wander around and see amazing things around every corner. It is simply a delight to get lost in.

There is so much to see and explore in this area.. You can walk through this area many times and keep seeing new places. Following the map is a good idea, but be aware that many of the street maps only label the more popular roads so you could get momentarily lost.....but isn't that part of the attraction of exploring Rome? I would suggest a decent Guide to Rome and map to get the best out of your trip and be prepared to walk! ( I use Lonely Planet guide to Rome and find it really helpful because I like to make sure I see as much as I can), Lots of shops and trattoria to browse or enjoy a snack etc.

A beautiful piece of history. Rome has so many amazing buildings and statues it is hard to decide which is best, but you should not miss Centro Storico as a place to stop and wonder at the buildings and statues.

Lost in the middle of Rome.... I know Rome very well and I've lost my way tons of times, but I have always ended up in some places. Maybe it was unexpected, but this is one of my favorite thing about Rome. When you're walking in the city centre is easy to get to all the places and see all the monuments, but also discover new places, streets, restaurants, shops. Trastevere and Monti are the best if you're looking for some alternative gift:) You can see where famous movies were shooted and you can talk with other tourists, you can stroll around without an aim, go to the museums or, in case, even take a train to visit some nice small cities that are pretty close, likeTivoli and Bracciano, even the sea at Santa Severa!

Get Lost in the Ambiance. We took an evening stroll through a number of neighborhoods in Rome and we can see why people love Rome. We passed by this site and there were many restaurants and street performers that added to the ambiance. It made the stroll very memorable.

A massive monument. Most of our journeys around the City involved walking past this massive building. The statues are so impressive. We didn't want to queue to go to the top in the small, tall lift so instead walked around the back to the mid level and that was a pretty good view - over the Roman forum and towards the Colosseum.

How can you describe it.....?. This has to be one of the most difficult reviews to write. The problem is, where to begin and where to end. There is so much to see and do in the Center of Rome that it would take a lifetime to fully discover. From historical landmarks to beautiful bars and restaurants, there is a pulse and energy to the city that simply can’t be compared to anything else. Of course you’ll have the negative aspect, which is the population of Rom Gypsies and other miscreants running amok selling whatever. However, the absolute beauty and heartbeat of this city can’t be beat. One of my favorite things to do while in Rome, is sit right in the middle of the hustle and bustle at one of the bars in Piazza Venezia, in front of the Vittoriano, and simply people watch. Another one of my favorites is grabbing your ipad, a book, and go to a bar in Piazza della Rotonda, and again get a nice beverage and relax, watch the world go by and simply soak it in. Another spectacular part of being in Rome is the people. Absolutely fantastic. By and large Romans are willing to help you get where you need to go. Lucky for me I speak Italian and grew up on the outskirts of Rome. However, I own a niche travel agency and seldom hear complaints from clients I send to these locations. They truly enjoy all the beauty in the Eternal City. If you haven’t been yet, you have to go and experience this unique, chaotic, and absolutely gorgeous city on the banks of the Tiber river.
A place to wander and drop into the hidden sites. A place to take your time and visit the old streets and piazzas with some gems of works of art in the many churches.

Enjoy your walk. Historical centre of Rome is always beautiful, it doesn't matter if it is day or night time, if it sunny or raining. It is always full of people and great, calm atmosphere. I just love it!
centro storico. We stayed in the Centro Storico area, it was a lovely area to wander around, some very nice restaurants and ice cream parlours.

By foot. When traveling with children I try to calculate the trips and use as little extra services as possible. Therefore we tried to explore Rome on foot and we managed it. Choose different departure points and explore.

How wonderfull so many monuments in a short walk!. Rome it's a city where the average walker don't need a taxi or even a bus.
You can take or time, your photos and even your lunch while you discover all the wonders of Rome during a pleasant walk!

A large vibrant area of historic sights and great street life.. To wander round this area is to be distracted at every turn. Every church is fascinating. There are marvellous historic buildings, a maze of streets with unexpected shops - anyone for an ecclesiastical outfit? there are cafes with views, on squares, down alleys, restaurants offering everything form simple pizzas to oysters and Roman specialities. There are famous fountains thronged with people taking selfies and local citizens heading to work in Government offices or having a drink after work. A great place to stay but you might want to consider where the metro stations are before you book a hotel.

Do not miss it!!!. Do not miss the Centro Storico Rome,it's full of history, with its beautiful buildings, squares, monuments and all very walkable to each other. Really no words to describe the beautiful historical city centre of Rome!! It is unique in the world and very special. Absolutely do not miss it.

The Heartbeat of Rome. The heartbeat of Rome is around the Piazza della Rotunda and the Pantheon. There are several good restaurants and a very good hotel--The Albergo del Senato nearby. Fabulous coffee places in Tazza d"Oro and Sant"Eustachio.

Excellent. This area, known in ancient Roman times as the Campus Martius, was outside the city centre, a low-lying area that was mostly given over to barracks and sporting arenas, together with several temples, including the Pantheon. Later it became the heart of the Renaissance city, and nowadays it’s the part of the town that is densest in interest, an unruly knot of narrow streets and alleys that holds some of the best of Rome’s classical and Baroque heritage and its most vivacious street- and nightlife.

Magnificent. It's the eternal city. The only city worthy of Paris (by Paris's own admission). One of the truly great cities of the world. For better or for worse, an experience onto itself, a city unlike any other yet much like many. For anyone visiting Europe, Rome, and its historic center in particular, are an absolute must. Takes at least a week to properly sightsee and months to actually absorb. Magnificent.
Roma is Rome. If you want visit Rome u can't miss also little things in downtown. Rome is huge and you need different days to can experience it pretty well. Rome is Rome!!1
Magnificent place. Magnificent place. Every corner is a surprize. You never feel bored. Many options for nice wine drinking.

Centre of history. If you love history , this is the place to visit. Make sure you do your homework beforehand,otherwise you may get lost and frustrated. A week is the minimum, a life is what you need to cover,understand, and internalize.
Beautiful. And charming with all those piazzas, interesting people and a lot of good food and coffee... Love it!

Ah, Roma!. Great city to walk. Surprises you at every corner. You almost remember walking through the old city during Roman times. The weather was great and the food, super Magnifico! We rented an apartment on the Prati district, near Vatican city, through Airbnb, WikiRome, that was great. Very close to everything and very lively. Highly recommend it. We even heard the bells of the Vatican after Easter Mass said by the Pope. And Gregorian chant at the Santa Maria in Trastevere church. An incredible experience! Go and enjoy everything that Rome offers (and it's a lot!).

The heart of the City. You can enjoy every thing around here the views, the restaurants, the shops, central location and worth visiting for anyone around in Rome. Watch out for beggars/ photo takers they tend to request for more.

wander around..... There are marvels on every corner; ancient remains, beautiful churches and squares. There are also pleasant streets with good cafes and restaurants and of course the famous ice cream parlours/

Rome at its finnest. Situated right in the middle of the city, this historic centre have everything at its surroundings. Shops, restaurants, atractive spots to visit. Would definately suggest it.Wonderful ruins. Beware for the "turists robbers" always looking around for a peak of your camera or your wallet. Make sure you leave your most caring belongings in the hotel.

Amazing City. I am blown away with every bend and twist in the road. It seems as though you stumble across the most amazing things around each corner. Take a walk and don't be surprised when you come across something you were not expecting.
What a mix of different centuries. The historic centre of Rome is a real mix of structures and buildings from almost every century. There really is something for everyone.
Treasures in every corner. It's compact, walkable and full of surprises. There's a church in every corner. We were told that there were more than 800 of them in Rome.

Rich In History. Oldest church dedicated to Virgin Mary from the third century. It is filled with mosaics of the medieval period, if you put some coins in the light box you can see the mosaics light up. Admission is free.
Great city. The entire city of Rome looks like a museum. The sculptures are beautiful and the architecture is so seductive.

BEAUTIFUL SITES AND HASSLE FREE. One of the only places in Rome where we weren't hassled constantly by street sellers and tour guides!!!! A very pleasant walk around the amazing structures a lot of artists there but you could view there work without them hassling you which was a rarity!!!!!
What can you say IT IS ROME. There's so much to see and that one can become overawed.Organised walking tours a re a good idea then if you want to revisit anything at leisure you can.

Historic Heart of Rome. All within walking distance, you can see great Piazzas ( Navone, di Spagna,, Trevi Fountain,)great churches and their fine art ( St Ignatius,Maria di Papola), not to mention main attractions like the Coliseum, and great restaurants.

Amazing. I cannot begin to describe how much I enjoyed our short trip to Rome. We booked a hotel right in the centre of the city and did A LOT of walking. Every street has a beautiful church or a monument or a quaint little restaurant for tourists to enjoy. There are also loads of shops everywhere, including gift shops. It's just amazing, there are museums everywhere and most attractions are within walking distance. The food was great and so were the ice cream and coffee. It was very busy as it was Easter time but still it was an amazing trip. There are also loads of ruins everywhere! We mostly walked but also took the metro to the Vatican, which was full of grafitti and the stations were quite dark; however, it was extremely cheap and very fast, so I was still impressed. I definitely want to go back, I totally recommend it.
Get lost and enjoy !. walk walk walk and get the best Rome feeling ! the centre offers at every steps something to discover and enjoy !

A walker's delight. We have been in Rome more than eight times for extended stays, and always we walk several times through the Centro Storico, especially to the west of Piazza Navona. It is a slow walk we make, taking time to look at the architecture, the shops, and the people. The BLUE Guide Rome offers the first time walker an excellent itinerary, but I am sure there are other equally good guides. Via del Governo Vecchio is a treat as is via del Coronari. Before walking, read up about the area and prepare yourself for one of the great pleasures to be found in Rome, and it is all free. There are some good restaurants and ice cream shops along the way, for both I recommend the small shops. Lunch time will find the better eateries full. A whole history of sixteenth and seventeenth century Roman architecture is here. Enjoy, but do it slowly.
beautiful site. architecture and archaeology and history. Must see art work as well. Worthwhile visit. Incredible the craftsmanship.

Campo is our Home Base.... We wanted to be in the Centro Storico, and we sure are. Very central for...well... everything, really....all of Roma is just out our front door. Shopping, churches, restaurants, historical sites; it's all here, depending on which way you walk. I do worry about how the Campo di Fiori area might smell in the heat of summer....
Lots to see and even more to taste both food and drink. Living In Centro Storico You are close to everything within 15 minutes walk you have posibilityes for a Liftime

Rome doesn't get enough attention as a great free walking city. I've been a serious traveler my whole life and enjoyed close to forty countries --about a third many times and lengthily- including two thirds of both America and Canada. Insofar as walking cities are concerned, New York, Paris, London and Rome -in no particular order- are my favorite of the largest ones.With the cheap transportation cards good on trollies, buses and trains, and systems easy to follow, Rome drops you at a score of starting points for some of the richest freebie and cheap options in which to fill a day. If New York is the big Apple, then Rome is surely the Peeling Onion, as history unfurls layer by layer in a multitude of wildly varied contexts.For those without language ease, I've always felt Italians generally are most patient, proud of their surroundings and desirous to help. If the first or second request isn't generous (rarely happens), by the third you may wind up with a trip biographer.And ladies so far as I can tell, the annoying pinch is long a relic of bin history along with cigarette holders, thin mustaches and halo brimmed hats. It seems the major major mistakes one can make in Rome involve not being fiscally discreet or putting oneself a but too far to get ask early enough. Other than that, there are few wrong directions. one isa great city in which to get a little lost when fitting pieces excitingly is not a requirement. it's hard imagining more than a few who wouldn't elect at least one more day exclusively for leisure in any quadrant of Rome.

Camera verloren/ lost photocamera. I have lost my photocamera on 22-03 or 23-03 in the centre of Rome, Trastevere or around the Colosseum/ Forum Romanum. It is a black panasonic photocamera in a pink bag with flowers. I've anyone found it please let me know, the photos are very important to us

nice though .... go around the Roman historical center is a really nice experience for those who love to immerse themselves in the history of this wonderful city, because at every corner sprouting monuments, construction, works of art to visit or even just to see. also it offers a great deal for those who want to shop, having a multitude of shops even higher level, with artisanal production of many types. There are all categories that you need. the only thing I have to say in negaticvo is that the cost of what you buy to eat in the old town is really high. you can get to pay much even a bottle of water, which in my opinion is not very fair. Beware of ZTLs. This is one of Europe's must-see historical centers, which includes sites like the Colosseum, Pantheon, Roman Forum, Trevi Fountain, and Spanish Steps. All are within walking distance of one another, but if you want to use the metro, buy a BIT Standard Ticket at any station for 1.50 euro, which allows you a 1-way trip of any distance (100-minute time limit is enforced if you're using the bus); Rome has the simplest public transit system in Europe because there are only 2 metro lines that run like an "X" through the city. And don't even think about driving because the extensive ZTLs and suicidal tendencies of Italian drivers will make for a terrible time.

Essential sights close to each other. This historic center of Rome is perfect for those who can walk. Start at the Largo Argentina, a collection of four ruined ancient Roman temples along the main street (Corso) where buses run. Walk north toward the Pantheon. Stop at S. Maria sopra Minerva church to see Michelangelo's "Risen Christ." Look at the wonderful sculpted elephant holding an obelisk, by Bernini. A few more steps bring you to the Pantheon, the greatest of Roman temples, the magnificent domed cylinder that represents the world of the gods of the Roman Empire. Slightly west is the university, the Sapienza, and if the church of St. Ivo is open, you will see a spectacular interior, by the great architect Borromini. Then northward to Piazza Navona, on the site of a Roman stadium (which can be visited, underground, entrance on a street to the north of the piazza). On this piazza is a splendid church of St. Agnes by Borromini and others, and three magnificent fountains, the central one (representing four rivers) being one of Bernini's great masterworks. Nearby are the churches of San Luigi dei Francesi with a spectacular chapel by Caravaggio and another beautiful one by Domenichino, and S. Maria della Pace with fine architecture by Pietro da Cortona and interior frescoes including beautiful sibyls by Raphael. The German national church of S. Maria dell'Anima, around the corner, has been beautifully restored recently. Then treat yourself to some gelato at Giolitti, a venerable and famous gelateria nearby.

Bring Walking Shoes and an Appetite for History... and Food!. Thousands of years of history are piled on-top-of one another in the Centro Storico. All you need is a pair of great walking shoes and you can discover from sun-up to sundown. Feel free to wander into any obscure church on any alley - you may find a beautiful Carvaggio painting on the wall like we did. Do not waste your time with breakfast (grab a cappuccino), or lunch (just order a prosciutto on focaccia bread at any one of the little osterias on the way). For dinner, try to find a place away from one of the major areas (Pantheon, Piazza Navonna, etc.,), as you will usually pay for the views rather than the food. Once you find a nice place for dinner (look for somewhere with a line), be prepared to sit down for a couple hours. If you are looking for nightlife, I'd wander over to Campo di'Fiori or Trestevere across the river.Extra tip: they say Rome is best discovered slowly, so don't be afraid to just sit on one of the fountains and watch the day fade away. Also, wake up early and get outside because it's fun to watch the Centro Storico come alive with people.

Rome – eternal and open city. It’s no use – everything that can be said about Rome was already said by someone sometime. And you cannot even start imagine Rome until you been there. For longer or for shorter time – it still be too short. It is amazing city, where buildings were erected not by demolishing old ones, but incorporating them, so that you can see Roman colonnade in a wall of medieval church or Roman figures gazing from a house in former ghetto area. There can be no advice about Rome – everyone has to find their own ways and places. And do not plan your trip too strictly or to follow map itinerary too exactly, because Rome will overturn all your plans, will lead you other way and still bring you to see some gem which you neither knew nor planned to visit. All you need – to open your eyes and heart. The eternal city will open to you, too.
