Great time travel within a compact area. Settle in your room quickly and just get on a bus, say 81 that takes you around the most important sites like the Colosseum, Forum Romanum and Palatinus, Circus Maximus, Piazza Venezia. Hop off on Corso Vittorio Emanuele, stroll in the small, narrow streets, get a nice caffee and a slice of pizza in a little osteria near Piazza Navona to have a feel and a first experience of the city, even if you arrive for business and have limited time. If you have days, check out all the places one by one and indulge in the time travel of art and history.
Roma is Roma. If you know it you love it if you do not know it you have to visit it....every traveller should spend some time in this beautiful city

Stunning. The historic center of Rome is absolutely stunning, history, myths and legends around every corner, from semi modern buildings to ancient historical sites. One thing I would advise is be aware of the prices where you choose to eat or drink, we found on a couple of occasions that the price you see is not the price you are expected to pay, it left us very wary about eating in the center for fear of being ripped off.
amazing historic. Don't miss the main square with its 3 fountains - piazza navona. Also the Pantheon is amazing and free!
Amazing. So much to see and so much to do in this fantastic city, bring good walking shoes as lots of walking requires.

The best open-air museum in the world - il centro storico di Roma. Rather than reading this, go there. Just walk and walk, forget any Google maps, just look around you, enjoy the buildings, the people, stop for un espresso or un gelato and say thank you for being in Rome.
Roman history. Very impressed by the variety of architecture some of it obviously very old. I could picture the Romans wandering around.
The place to be. Just stand there and imagine what was the life of those romain peoples during Julius or Neron's life... We can't.

Best Part of Rome. The ancient Historical Center, or Centro Historico. So many of the fabled things you've heard about are in this central, easily accessible. Plus great food. Shopping not so much, but who cares? There is so much you could not possible see it all in many visits. I would never stay in any other area.
Beatiful Rome!!. Rome is wonderful, you can see art everywhere...it was so exciting to discover many monuments that I never seen before.!
Centro Storico of Rome. Came by here from the airport.I didn't enter the place but from what I saw from the outside, its a good place to spend sometime, but not for long in my opinion.
One of a kind!. Simply the best! History, culture and its glory! Never fail to visit this place when in Rome, the very first to be re-visited again and again!
Stunning!. We loved seeing this building and all of the displays inside. You can learn quite a lot about Italian history, the newer information we don't study in humanities class.

The heart of Rome. Rome's Centro Storico is the epicentre of the city and contains some of the main must see attractions.
If you visit the centre of Rome it is enviable you will spend time in the Centro Storico.
It is one of my favourite cities in the world and it does not get much better than the Centro Storico.
Really easy to walk around. I had no idea all these famous Roman things were really so close to each other and it made it really easy to walk or hop on and off the train. Very cool.
There is no place like Rome. Wander about, drink it all in, read about it, visit all the places you can, this is one of the most amazing places in the world.

Top five places to visit in the world.. 2500 years of history packed into a few square miles. You could literally spend your life visiting and studying Rome's Centro Storico and you would continue to make great discoveries every day. Layers of history. The deeper you go into the ground the farther back you go. Don't visit by car, you'll move too fast to appreciate. Even walking can be too fast to see the sites. Even if a particular important location is closed on the inside, say the Pantheon, when you happen to pass by, no matter, see it from the outside, drop by Piazza Navona, see the Fontana di Trevi, the Spanish Steps, or simply wander down the narrow streets which are mostly composed of medieval construction using ancient Roman remains.

So what are we reviewing here?. What is the Old Town or the Centro Storico ? The city center around Pantheon, Fontana di Trevi, the Vatican, and such, or is it the Roman Forum and the Roman sites? If you go by the original meaning of “storico”, it has to be the Roman monuments so have a look at these respective reviews. For those who think that it is the area around the Pantheon, Piazza Navona and the Campo dè Fiori: yes, there are lots of historic buildings as well as old apartment houses which will attract and require your attention, but not really related to the origin of Rome. At the same time, during tourist season, this area is crammed with tourists (which does not mean that there are fewer people on the Roman sites) which does not make it real fun when you go there then and follow the main stream. But when you leave the main routes, you will be able to dive into the real capital with quiet streets, nice shops, beautiful osterias, and all of this normally priced. But there is a price you have to pay: you have to speak Italian. You will awarded by a great friendliness and helpfulness from the people living and working there.
Super beautiful. This is just such a stunning building and watching it was the sun set and bounced off its beautiful white facade was a holiday highlight for me.

Rome is a magical place. I never tire of Rome, despite at least 10 visits there. The history, the sights, the food, the museums, the people, the walkability--everything about it is wonderful. Be prepared for crowds. Visit sites early in the morning. Buy tickets on line before travel, or work with the hotel or information centers to get access to museum and Vatican and other special sites without long lines. Only have a day or two--take a hop on/hop off to get a quick overview of many of the best things. Venture into Trastevere for a less hectic, more homey experience--and find little neighborhood trattorias for the best dining experiences rather than the restaurants surrounding the most popular tourist sites. Find a café and enjoy great Italian coffee and watch the street theatre pass in front of you. Be aware of your belongings at all times and you will have a wonderful time in this magical city.

Lots of good walks to be done in this area of Rome. Explore the streets - lots of great history and architecture.Get a good guidebook and map and go and loose yourself.Lots of fun and lots of enjoyment to be had.
Rome visit. Fantastic, put this place on your list to visit these buildings are so architecturally interesting as so many are in Rome

worth seein. i was very impressed !
such a beautiful place to visit.
i love this architecture so i recommend this place to everybody.
Historical beauty. Rome has the most historical places & sites to see can spend so much time at many of them so make sure you allow time to see them all

Historical Paradise. The ancient city centre. Many of the historical sites and attractions are within a 3 kilometer radius. All of it are walkable providing one enjoys to walk a few kilometers. One can see all the sites within this city centre in one day. But it is best to dedicate 3 days or more to absorb and appreciate the architecture and cafés all around. We walked and saw the Trevi fountain, Pantheon and Piazza Navona in 1 day. The rest of the other sites on the other days during our stay in Rome. It is also the cleanest part of Rome and the best area to stay in Rome.
Breathtaking at every turn. One of the world's most beautiful cities and in the Centro Storico there is an incredible range of architecture from the last 2000 years.
My dream vacation. One of many places we walked to. Rome is such a walk friendly city, we not once took public transportation to anywhere in Rome.

Not sure what the specific spot really is.... Overwhelming by the Campo de Fiori, hotel buses somewhat chaotic, best for those with comfort of city travel, otherwise not much right there, though we found much more on a map close by after. Though not really novices, ended up wasting much time waiting for hotel bus, without option for restaurant/eatery as a waiting spot. Also took a bus from the airport to what they claimed was the City Center, but was actually the Termini, about 3K away, close to an hour walk. Be careful with choice of bus from FCO.
Amazing. Roma centre is really amazing. It's impressive to walk through small streets and all of by sudden you Discover fantastic monuments
I'M SO BLESSED. I saw the Pope by the window, blessing the crowd in Italian. I had goosebumps with the clapping of the people.... It was a blessing to see the Pope..

Sunday at St Peters Square. We made a special trip to be at the square at noon so we couldsee Pope Francis (along with thousands of others) on October 25 at the closing of the synod on family. Easy to spot his window -there were also jumbotrons and an excellent sound system. He spoke for quite a while - identifying national groups in the crowd (to their delight). A very moving experience..

The Landmark of the Christian Faith...Centro Storico. Rome was our second destination in a 14-day tour of Europe. Greece namely Athens and Santorini was our first leg and after 6 days we flew to the Vatican City of Italy. Our first day was spent in the Vatican Museum and we decided to meet on the second day at Centro Storico. This is a huge square with two huge fountains with rippling water that gushes forth. At the center of the Square is the Obelisk, the historical gift from Cleopatra, Queen of Egypt to Augustus Caesar. Thee were a lot of people, tourists, Italians and church worshippers that milled around the square. Everyone had a chosen spot for favorite picture taking. Others pose in the middle of the square to have a panoramic perspective of the magnificent St. Peter's Basilica. Some prefers the background of the water fountains and a few likes the obelisk, a symbol of power and undying love.
People magnet !. surrounded by 2500 years of history this is a beautiful part of Rome but very very crowded - worth it despite the crowds
Amazing. Amazing but didn't get to go inside due to a long wait, the que was just too long and didn't want to waste time queuing upMust go and see.
Simply great Architecture. Couldn't get enough of the wonderful hand made architecture. You can never get bored with such awesome work

Amazing. Our visit to Vatican City exceeded all our expectations.Highly recommend paying that bit extra and join a guided tour,as without it we would have missed loads.It truly was the highlight of our trip to Rome.Do not miss.
Give yourself time. So much to see you need a day to take it all in the church ,the square ,the museum and remember the Chappell
Amazing Artifact. Rome never ceases to amaze me at the level of engineering brilliance the early Romans achieved. Brovo.
Very Busy Spot. Very impressive standing around in this square, just as seen on the T.V keep your eye on your wallets etc as its know for this hobby.

A Must for a Stroll - but Look Out for the Crowds. I visit part of the Centro Storico every time I visit Rome - and I visit frequently. On my last, very recent trip I promised myself to see only places I'd not yet seen, but I broke that promise early the first full morning I spent in the the Eternal City and made a beeline for some of my favorite places in Rome - the Pantheon, Piazza Navona, Campo dei Fiori etc etc etc. I am never disappointed. Even relatively early on a Sunday morning I had to elbow through tour groups - I've come to loathe those bright umbrellas of guides forging ahead at all costs to get their groups the best of all possible views) at the Pantheon, which I consider the most beautiful building in all of Rome - and that's saying a lot for it, as Rome is overpacked with stunners. While you will probably get confused as to direction on your first time through it's worth it - someone very wise once said, "In order to discover a city one must get lost in it." Don't be afraid, the Corso is only steps to the right or left of your most wished-for sites/sights!

The clean part of Rome. On plus: it is one of the few places in Rome that are not dirty and messy. I will strongly suggest to visit Centro Storico after dark. It is giving much better effect with the light of street lanterns.On minus: it is mostly open for traffic so you will need to avoid taxis, residents cars and scooters.

And historic it is too!. Whether you are in Piazza San Pietro flanked by the columns of Bernini's great arcades, standing in Piazza Farnese looking up at Michelangelo's wonderful facade to the Farnese Palace or wandering among the market stalls in Campo di Fiori under the bronze gaze of Giodano Bruno, one cannot fail to be imbued with a sense of history......2,500 years of history in fact.Yet Rome is not an historic stage set. It is a living, breathing and absolutely vital city. Wander its back streets and you will see all kinds of busy activities, cabinet makers at work, shopkeepers serving their local customers, chefs cooking away in restaurant kitchens, old ladies lowering baskets from upper stories for their groceries. Vecchia Roma (Old Rome) is a palimpsest. Civilisations have written and re-written over her for two and a half millenia. If you stand in Piazza Argentina, the excavated ground level of the ruins is 4-5 metres below you. What I love about Rome's historic centre is how little things change. The Roman way of life lives on. I love buying a slice of crisp breakfast pizza with a thin coating of tangy tomato in the Forno Farnese at the western end of Campo di Fiori, or "un bel caffe" in the Bar Farnese, or a luncheon slice of pizza from the Pizza by the Slice (pizza al taglio) in Piazza Pollarolla. What's not to like?

Fabulous. Downtown Rome is as great as I remembered my first visit being....more than 40 years ago. Crowed but well worth it. Can't wait to go back. One thing to note. At the metro stop by the Trevi Fountain we got jammed up by pick pockets as we got on the metro who unsuccessfully tried to steal our stuff. Don't let this stop you from going, but keep a very firm hand on your bag no matter how crowded the metro trains are. Nevertheless, Il Centro Storico is not to be missed...

More than you can imagine. Get to Vatican City as early as you can. Be prepared to be touched and bumped by a lot of people. Bathrooms are hard to come by once you're on the path through the museum/Basilica so carefully think about your liquid/food consumption strategy. Plan to be here for an entire day. Take a cab back and forth - totally worth the crazy driving/price.If you are coming during hot weather - bring a hand fan, water, sunscreen. It was lovely in October but I can't imagine how hot this could be in mid summer. If you are doing the Vatican museum tour, book your tickets ahead of time online and try to get an early entrance time. I'm going to emphasize early over and over again because the number of people that come here every day is hard to imagine until you see it. It rivals Disney during spring break for a much smaller space. Get a map. There are two "versions" of the Vatican museum tour, long and short. We did the short version which gets you to the Sistine Chapel quick. We went back through and saw everything we missed on a second pass that skipped the Sistine chapel. There are a ton of tours moving through and it could be worth it to do one. We bought a book ahead of time and did our own research then just went and appreciated what we saw. And it's amazing. The Sistine chapel is hard to describe, it's different than expected, both bigger and smaller. Be prepared to be shushed over and over again. Also, no shorts or exposed shoulders. The only terrible part about the place is the cafeteria - do not get sucked into buying the lunch there, the food is terrible and the service is decidedly un-Christian. St. Peter's Basilica is free - the horrifying long line you see if for security, not tickets. It moves fast when the security officers feel like doing their job well. When they all go on a smoke break at the same time it stops. Teenagers try to cut the line - don't let them. Once you are through the line, you get as much time as you like in the space. Again, it's hard to describe, only it's much larger and grander than anything you could possibly imagine. It made me cry and I am not religious. You will be shushed a lot and still no shorts or bare shoulders. We didn't do a tour but you may enjoy one, it's an experience even without one. There is an additional museum inside you can pay for. Even if you have already seen a lot of churches in your travels, this one is the one you can't miss.

Only go if you are really interested. Take a tour if you do. We bought a beat the queue tour outside, which meant we only spent just over 2 hours queuing outside. Apparently this is unusually bad, but we were told it is not unusual for those queuing individually to do so for 6 hours.I like art but by the time we got to the Sistine chapel I was that tired that I could hardly be bothered to look up. I felt like we were herded through like cattle.Everyone says you have to see it, but unless you have a specific interest this takes up most of a day and there are lots of more interesting places in Rome which don't take up so much time and you don't have to put up with the pushing and shoving.Maybe we were unlucky, but everyone I spoke to who went that day says they wish they hadn't bothered.

Yet another must see in Rome.. I've been to 139 countries on all seven continents so have seen a hell of a lot but this wss my first time in Rome and it has totally blown me away. Even in important historic cities like London and Paris there isn't the profusion of historical sites. Every corner you come around offers something new and enthralling. Importantly they are all so easily accessible on foot.

An incredible insight to the Vatican. To get the best of of visiting The Vatican - is it very much worth being part of a tour. We went with Walks Of Italy and they were first class. If we didn't have a guide we would have dfeinitely missed a lot out. Only down side to whole afternoon there were the officious looking security guards when we visited the Sistine Chapel as they bellowed out "No Photo" " No speaking" every 30 seconds or so. Complely ruined the peace and tranquilty of the experience there.Wouldn't say that this is very suitable for young children.

A Day at Vatican City. I would advice to take a day to visit the Vatican city and all it has to offer... St. Peters Cathedral & the Sistine chapel, the square and the surroundings. I would suggest to top the day of and walk to Pizzarium Bonci for one of the best Pizza by the slice in Rome!
Amazing. Just to walk around this place is fantastic. You were hoping that the pope himself would open the window and wave.

Vatican City Rome. A fantastic day out you could really spend a day and more to take everything in St Peters Basillica,the Sistine chapel ,museum so much to see and to really appreciate this you must visit a guide is good as you can walk around without getting getting the full meaning of all you see I enjoyed it and can recommend to see

Looks like Vatican. Very Impressive and Scenic! We are Christians ...but not of the Catholic faith. Our friends are and we have attended Catholic services with them. This visit is very impressive and memorable. We have been here at least 2 times as our cruise on Royal Caribbean has this location as a main visit site.

Absorb the spirit and atmosphere. It was a stunning Autumn day, Thursday around noon. The square of St Peters was busy but not crowded. My visit to St Peter's Basilica and surrounds left me feeling real gratitude to be in such a beautiful place. Though the lines looked long, they moved quickly and entering St Peter's happened quite fast. There was much to see while waiting, every step, or turn worthy of a photo. The visitors came from everywhere and yes, lots of selfies were taken by people and groups in the square and the Basilica, but it did not matter. It's a huge space, there's room for all. I don't think you need a tour or guide, in fact they seem a distraction unless you want every fact. Experience the beauty, the art, the grandeur, the detail. Wander slowly. Highly recommend, don't be turned off by the queues, it's worth it.
.... Incredible... there is no words to describe the feelings that you can feel... A must! Another piece of history to see in your live.
Breathtaking. It is hard to describe because it will take your breath away. Words cannot describe how beautiful it isClose buy is St peters Basicla and the Sistine Chapel. DO NOT MISS

The heart of historic Rome. If you can, try to plan your visit to Rome so that you stay in a hotel or lodging in the Centro Storico, so you can tumble out of your room in the morning and explore all day. If you’re staying elsewhere, definitely spend some time here! Within easy walking distance, you’ll find the Piazza Navona, the Pantheon, palazzos, fountains, piazzas, museums, churches, and monuments galore. Many of the smaller streets are pedestrianized, or almost pedestrianized (watch out for the occasional car or motorcycle!) while the major streets are likely to carry large amounts of traffic. The area is not well served by the Metro, but trams and bus routes provide access. The Largo Argentina is a hub for many bus routes. There are dozens of restaurants and gelato shops, and nothing is better than just enjoying the cafes and streets. Duck into a church during open hours and admire the mosaics and sculptures and paintings and marble floors. Cross the Tiber on one of the bridges and look back at the city domes and spires and rooftops. Walk through the Jewish Ghetto and find the ancient buildings adapted for more modern uses. You could spend an afternoon there or a week. But definitely go!
Nice place for photos.. We walked around and took a bunch of photo's. The square is beautiful and the rounded architecture is worth of too many photos.
Unmissable. This is where it all happens. Everywhere you look, history is staring back at you. St Peter's is a must as are the Vatican Museum and the Sistene Chapel.

Buzzing with activities & sights. So much to see and do, great cafes, gelato shops, restaurants etc. Really you can't come to Rome without exploring this area. It is very crowded as a result, and traffic is not great, but I wouldn't miss it for the world!

The most historical capital of the world, I think. 2500 year of history where you can walk from end to end in an hour. Bridge from 62 (?) BC, ruins from even older days, church build as a pagan temple in approx. 115 AD, continuously in use. Where else can you find this in a modern city?Yes, it is overfloaded with cars and tourists and beggars and sellers (umbrellas in rain, all kinds of other stuff when it doesn't), and I don't like much people and noise, but I just have to return once or twice a year.

Pleasant space (center). So interesting to discover Rome by walking the narrow & paved narrow pedestrian streets. Lots of ice cream shops, Enoteca restaurants & Dolce cafeterias are spread all over its length.Rome is a very charming city.... an Open air Museum
Great place. One of the highlights of the visit. Enjoy the view from The top of the cupola. Worth the effort of climbing up the narrow stairs for a great view of Rome.
Great place!. Get there early to avoid all the queues. Pretty surreal standing there and taking in the atmosphere.

Still wonderful to visit after 8 times in Rome over the years.. We love the Centro Storico of Rome. We love walking the streets, taking in the amazing history, finding new great shops, eating great food, watching the people. What's not to love.

Amazing!!!. No matter how many times you have been here before it is always a really great experience to walk in the narrow streets of the historic Centre of Rome. You can feel all the rich history of the city.

Friday afternoon visit.. So many people trying to sell selfie sticks and tours. Had to stand in line for security to St Peter's Basilica for about 40 minutes at 4pm. We finally got in and had to go to the bathroom. straight ahead is the bathrooms and for women about a 20 minute line. By the time we were done cupula was closed at 5pm. This is a free part of the Vatican tour. Beautiful inside. Parts are closed from pictures. Coming out and having to use bathroom again (too much wine w/ lunch) and the outside ones were closed. Guard said just closed go back toward the security point and to the left. The attendant was sleeping or playing Candy Crush for awhile. Someone tried to go past the third stall which was all blocked off and the attendant got irritated. The attendant then said it was time to close the bathrooms and only let about 5 of use in.The line for the basilica looks long but moves fast.
stunning. Has to be one of my favourite parts in Rome, I recommend taking time to walk in the narrow streets and discovering your own Rome as this is by far the best way to see this amazing city
Amazing. The historical part of Rome is not only for Catholic, but it will amaze everybody.Take your time, walk around " drink it in"

Visiting San Pietro Basilica. We decided to revisit the Basilica as it was very crowded in the afternoon. We went very early getting there at 7 in the morning. We're able to get some great photos as the sun came up. No long queues, hardly anyone in the Basilica. Would really recommend doing this as you get time to appreciate the amazing architecture.

Worth a visit. Purchased tickets through trip advisor before we left the uk. Saved time and money by doing this. Avoided all queues to enter the Vatican. The tour was long - 3hrs and hot with loads of people milling around. We took water in with us, but ended up sharing with others in our group which had no water. Although there were water points inside, apparently, we were never directed to any, nor did we get chance to stop whilst being shuffled through the rooms. still worth a look, the Sistine chapel is amazing.

Enormous and Unbelievable Architecture. This place is amazing and you cannot believe the size of the place and detailed architecture until you are stood there. The statues along the top of the pillars that encapsulate the area is truly stunning. Loved this

DONT BUY THE TICKETS ON THE STREET!. Well the St Pietro is a nice place, especially the square and the Basilica. BUT BE CAREFUL, ON THE WAY THERE MANY PEOPLE WILL TRY TO SELL YOU TICKETS TO SKIP THE LINE ETC FOR AT LEAST 50Euros, DONT DO IT. Go there in the morning to the square directly and you will wait in the line like 20 minutes with no payment to see square and basilica, If you will want you can continue from basilica to the sixtin chapel and museum for 25 euros.

AMAZING! A shame it is not very clean. I think that visiting Rome downtown area is one of the things that I liked the most while on vacation. The area is a lot larger than I thought and visiting it with a driver really made it a lot easier, since we only had a day to explore Rome. The only part I did not like were the writing (graffiti) on the walls... a real shame!!

Amazing place. Definitely I should visit again. Two days were't enough to see all the attraction in Rome city. Vatican is one of the great place to visit. Do not miss The Sistine Chapel, The Pietà (Vatican Museum).
impressive. the entire piazza and cathedral are impressive, a work of art in daylight and at night. San Pietro Basillica is located right in the piazza center and the view from the dome is amazing.

Purchase your tickets through tour that can avoid the long lines!. We purchased our tickets ahead of time through a tour group that was through our cruise ship. If we had not, we would have stood in line for hours. This attraction will take you several hours to see so plan accordingly. As a cruise ship occupant, we only had so many hours so we basically ran through everything to get a glimpse. It was very crowded and we had to work our way through tour groups.There are so many attractions in Rome but the Vatican is absolutely stunning. There is so much to see in the museum, the Sistine Chapel and St. Peter's Basilica.There were tons of beggars and people trying to sell stuff on the sidewalks outside. Be aware of pick pockets.

omg you can see the wealth of the vatican. Amazing architecture with history dripping just as with the rest of rome, the catholic church are not short of a trillion or two, great inside with relics from around the world

Breathtaking. As a non Christian I was truly blown away by the grandness and extent of craftsmanship that has made this truly incredible religious centre. It's quite incredible to see and witness first hand the power that the church once held, and to a certain extent still does. I do feel it is a little spoiled by the terrible unsightly screens erected permenantly for broadcasting the weekly blessing. With the money available, some more thought could go into this and they could be positioned away from blocking the view of the statues. As well as visiting in the day, a night viewing with everything beautifully lit is highly recommended.
to go on rainy day. to go and get lost to see the monuments , and the little corners and get lost again , ice cream on hand avoid the crowds as much as possible, if possible repeat

Pretty Grand. Even if you're not Catholic it's pretty hard to deny just how impressive the historic center of this city is, and just how mind-blowing the power of the Church once was. Just one of those things in Rome that you have to see under any circumstances.

Absolutely Fantastico. You will stand in awe at the magnificence of this place. Try and get here early to beat the queues as you could be waiting for three hours to get in. Highly recommend a visit here.

Book before you go!. If you're intending to visit the Vatican Museums which includes the Sistine Chapel its best to book direct online before you go. We booked the guided tour which was excellent. There's also a way from the museums into St Peters to avoid the queue!

Charmful, gigantic, beautiful. In no other city can get along so smoothly such different periods in the history !
And yet it tells a story that is always to be written again and will hardly stop. Not for nothing that, from its 2500 years of history we keep calling it the eternal city.

Immensely interesting. This is the historic center of rome and there are many beautiful monuments in this area. Starting from Piazza Navona to the Church Pantheon are all in this area. A must visit in Rome for any traveler.

Campo Martius. known as Campo Martius in ancient time Centro storico is a bit calmer than other tourist ares in Rome.The best known for its architecture, the abundance of which will surprise you.Plenty to see for free also , friendly and welcoming people.

Don't miss this one. One of the best places we visited. Absolutely stunning structure. You must climb in many steps to get inside. Do not miss the roof top. You will see all of Rome and then some! Cost is 3.50 euro for seniors7 for regular.
Vacation. Start your tour of this place from down the street and take pictures as you walk up the plaza. Very interesting.

This is a great city. When you come to Rome, you must stay in the centro. We've stayed in several areas - Spagna, Gesu, Laterano.... everywhere gives access to a vibrant centre day or night. There is so much to do and explore and every corner provides a photo opportunity.

GET A VIP TOUR FOR THE VATICAN MUSEUMS AND SAINT PETER'S BASILICA. Its such a beautiful place that you must invest in a private VIP tour. It will make all the difference regarding times, lines, explanations, wait times under the sun vs being inside. Its well worth to be there at 7:30am and start early. If you want to go alone, go late, after 4pm.

Ancient history everywhere. It was our first place we visited in Rome and quite an amazing place. Once you manage to control the crowded environment and the constant selfie stick salesman you can take time to appreciate the history. The following day was a trip into the Vatican and the chapel, we were with a tour and honestly it's the only way to go into the museum as the lineup outside goes for ever.

Not to be missed by first time visitors. The historic center of Rome is pretty big, but every square meter is worth exploring on foot. Not to be missed are the Piazza Navona and Campa dei Fiore but don't miss a stroll on the Via Margotta a hidden gem with great stores and restaurants close to the Spanish Steps.

The Nicest area in Rome. if you like wondering around small cobble stone streets discovering quirkie little shops, bars and restaurants, then Centro Storico is for you. The adjoining old Jewish ghetto also has lots of lovely areas to walk through.

Surrounded by Antiquity and History. Rome is like an open air museum. Mark all the points of interest you want visit on your map and then immerse yourself in the backstreets and alleyways to get there. It is amazing what you will come across along the way.

Just Pure Divinity. I think visiting the Basilica was one the most mystic experiences of my life. It's not only the cheer spirituality of the place, or the magnificence of the monument and all of its images and icons. It is clearly the weight of the history being displayed before your eyes. One shouldn’t die before see it and love it.
Amazing. Amazing, Rome is a city with history and culture for every places, i saw everything and i loved, we have much to learn with this city and monuments.
Rome - An Open Museum. Everywhere you look in Rome especially near the historic center you are surrounded by historical sights. Allow a good week here if you want to take most of it in.

Rome, one gigantic attraction.. What really is Centro Storico ? I suggest you first take a sightseeing bus tour of Rome to get your sense of where things are. How close to each other if they are, and a general feel for he city. Then walk, if weather accommodates. The sights are on every corner. If you are walking from one sight to another, every spot in between will be as spectacular. The architecture will amaze, the artwork will stun you and the statutes and marble sculpturing will leave you in awe. The Colosseo, Pantheon, Vatican, the thousands of churches, and don't say oh, it's a church. It's the richness of the art and culture of hundreds and even thousands of years ago that you are seeing. The piazzas, Palazzos, palaces, fountains, just ordinary buildings along the street that go back hundreds of years that have exquisite detail. Rome is just one gigantic attraction, with thousands of smaller attractions within it.

Can see this without crowds or paying fees. So Many Sights, So Compact!. Rome's historic center is amazingly easy to discover on foot and take in visually for free. I love it. WOW well worth the effort. definitely a must see in this remarkable city my advise to you all is that you get up early and beet the crowd so that you spend more of your day enjoying the wonderful landmarks and less time queuing in lines

Take a break in Rome!. Here's another review I missed from our January trip to Italy. This is a fantastic place to grab a gelato, take a seat, and just people watch. Your feet will hurt :). Rome is such a nice city and it is very interesting to visit it by foot and by yourself! Just walk around and discover it's hidden beauty.

Rome - Give Her a Week at Least!. Welcome to the Historic City of Rome, heart of the Old Roman Empire, home of the Catholic Church and the city where Caravaggio, Michelangelo and Bernini left their mark. This is one of those very special places where you find layer upon layer of history spanning the past two millennia. Rome is an amazing city to visit, sprawling with ancient ruins and structures, filled with decorative churches, littered with sumptuous fountains, elegant sculptures and worldly artworks. Rome has it all and lots of it - history, beauty, architecture, art, religion, gelato, pizza, espresso and much more.  Sadly, many arrive with only a few days to experience Rome. This translates into rather predictable and fixed itineraries focused on major attractions like the Vatican, Coliseum and Roman Forum with a handful of other places squeezed into whatever time is left before visitors leave Rome. Short stays mean sticking to the beaten path in Rome, which leaves a world of very good attractions unexplored. Visitors who are able to stay a week in Rome have it much better. Simply put, longer stays mean more time to see the major attractions as well as other interesting and important places in Rome that wouldn't be possible during short city-break trips to Rome.  So what to see in Rome? Rome has a daunting amount of possibilities when it comes to drafting an itinerary. I always recommend spending some time flipping through a good travel guide for Rome for starters. I like the DK Eyewitness book. I also suggest scrolling through online resources like these TripAdvisor Rome 'Things to Do' pages. This is a good way to come up with a list of places to visit that are meaningful to you personally.  Note: You might want to spend time researching on the TripAdvisor Rome forum where you can post your draft itinerary, allowing local experts and regular visitors to Rome to critique your itinerary and offer thoughts and suggestions that might help you plan an even better visit.  In the end, Rome is not for everyone and that is ok. However, for many, it is a remarkable destination, one that they will remember for many years after their visit. To these people, research as much as you can and enjoy as much time in Rome as your time and money will allow! Hopefully you will have opportunity for future visits as well.

go for it. part of the piazza navona, a brilliant showpiece and lots around to see. It will take most of a day with plenty stops, and there are several eateries, watch for the expensive ones, look for cheaper and just as good.

O lot of people, a mess.... Rome is a nice city to go, with a lot of monuments and very nice romantic places. However, the queue to visit the St. Peter Cathedral is horrible, as well as the Sistine Chapel. You must wait in the line more than one hour under the sun to reach the control machines in order to verify your belongings. Furthermore, women cannot show their shoulders or wear shorts or short salts, barred their entry.The cathedral is very beautiful, but you need to wait about two hours outside in the queue for spend 15 minutes watching the inside of the cathedral. For me, I preferred the surroundig areas of the Colosseum, the Spanish Steps, the Pantheon and other churches, fine dispersed by all the streets in Rome. Please take into account that many monuments of Rome are under restoration so, there are some limitations to the tourists.

Not to be Missed While in Rome. The best city in the world. Magical tiny streets.... Amazing place to wander around.. There's nothing wrong with doing tours, but there is something magical about wandering around a place like Rome's Centro Storica and letting yourself get lost in the tiny streets that are so subtle that you miss them if you don't look for them.. some people say that Rome's beauty lies on the inside and I didn't realize what that meant until I saw a car coming out of a courtyard and I had a look inside the courtyard and saw how stunning it was inside.. my experience in Rome has taught me not to just look at the obvious beauty you see everywhere but also look for the hidden treasures...and the Centro Storico is the place to find it!

Every corner is a chance for a new adventure, plunging into the past or surprise at the current day norms, the sense of scale is human in size, but a time machine for the mind and a carnival for the senses.

One day is not sufficient to visit the old town centre. You can sit and have a nice coffee in beautiful quite corners of Trastevere, enjoining Italian ice cream and food. Unforgettable.

Magical Rome. The Artemide Hotel is situated in the Centro Storico, so it was within reach of most of the major sights such as the Colosseum, The Roman Forum, The Pantheon, and many of the lovely piazza's and churches. The Vatican is a further distance away, but is walkable if you are fit! Otherwise all can be reached by bus, Metro or taxi. The traffic can be very congested, so a taxi fare could be rather steep. The Metro is quick and easy, but be aware that there are pickpockets in Rome, and be very careful with your personal possessions/ handbags/ wallets etc, especially around the big tourist areas and when using the local transport.

Far From the Maddening Crowds. This was my 3rd trip to Rome and I was so disappointed by the noise and the crowds. Centro Storico helped to restore my sanity. It is an old part of town with small, twisty streets and few tourists. We actually walked for several hours and did not hear any English being spoken. Not a flashy or touristy site, but it felt authentically Roman.

Wonderful Rome. We were lucky to go to Rome last year, and also in May this year.It is an absolutely beautiful, vibrant, bustling city, that makes you feel extremely insignificant!My advice would be; wear the most comfortable shoes that you own, buy the rough guide to Rome, as it's so informative and the map is brilliant, and see and experience all the beauty this city has to offer, as my friend said, keep your head up as there's always something to see and watch!I'd recommend the Colloseum, Vittorio Emmanuelle monument, (go in the glass lift for the best views, the Pantheon must not be missed, wander round back streets, see the Spanish steps, go into churches, drink wine, and eat wonderful food. If you love Italy Rome is perfect for you. Enjoy!
Many places to see!. Visit the center of Rome and you will be able to experience the Colosseum and Vatican. Do not miss it!

Wonderful to stroll around in a city that is like a big museum itself!. Walking in the old town is like being on a treasure hunt. Whereever you go there is always something new to explore, walls, statues, buildings, stores, signs - everything is so genuine!
amazing discovery. The grandeur of all the monuments to make me feel insignificant as I stood by them, the wonder of how they were built
lo n g walk. It's a long walking day. Too touristy. Restaurants are all over as well as street vendors. Churches and churches to visit. Pavers. Streets and people smoking everywhere

Pantheon. Only visited the Pantheon which was impressive and it contains Raphael's tomb. The architecture is interesting and the marble is stunning. Pity people were so noisy as they are supposed to remain quiet. Sadly, not enough time to visit more places in this area.
A good spot for a stroll. Rome is full of these little lanes and whether night or day, there will always be something happening. certainly worth a walk if you have the free time
Art and history. Rome is a very ancient city, and that is demonstrated in all the buildings and landmarks it has. You can also see some unknown pieces of art in some streets.

The Heart of Rome. Can't miss. Wonderful atmosphere at the piazzas, especially the Piazza Navona. Good restaurants abound, but best to go a block or more away from the main piazzas, usually. What architecture and color! Each church was a beautiful, spiritual experience that you don't have to be Catholic to enjoy.

This was the best place to shop and stroll. What a treat! Small streets with shops and restaurants, the Pantheon (2,000 years old), friendly people and safe. I love seeing important historical monuments and beautiful churches at every turn! What a beautiful city!

a very friendly and charming part of the city. We stayed in an apartment directly facing the pantheon. We spent 3 nights in Rome and walked around the historical center every day to go to our various destinations. It is a wonderful area, with many streets, churches, monuments, plazas to visit, shops and restaurants of all kind to see.
It is a little similar to the center of Firenze.

An enchanting atmosphere. It's of course redundant to say how beautiful Rome is. But its unique atmosphere and a tranquil given time only to the historic center if you are in a short trip is worth even is other parts of Rome are left unvisited.

my favourite area of Rome. walking around the centre of Rome is my favourite any time with its lovely squares such as Campo dei Fiori, Piazza Navona- narrow winding streets where you suddenly encounter an ancient column.

ONCE IS NOT ENOUGH. An amazing experience as you walk and feel the area unfold around you, there is so much to see and visit that it is almost overload. Every turn shows you a different piece of history. Don't rush from one site to another, give yourself time to sit and digest and plan your next visit.

Great walking neighborhood. This is a beautiful clean (except for all the cigarette butts all over just like the rest of Rome). The restaurants and stores are great. Of course some of the major attractions are here so be prepared to see a lot. This is a must-see area of Rome
Impressive. I do recommend seeing Coliseum, Pantheon, and Vatican City. But please do not forget to book all the visits before. If not you will send half of the day in the line.

Beautiful narrow streets, shame about the trash. Nice to walk around and discover the narrow cobbled streets. We found a great little tratoria for lunch. Nice and peaceful compared the the busy boulevards but a shame about the trash and rubbish scattered everywhere.

Unique experience!. Walking around the historical centre of Rome with all the monuments, the piazzas and the palazzi is a really unique experience that everyone has to have at one point of their life. Very sad it's so dirty, though! Real shame!
Terrific.. I want to return here someday soon. My time in Rome was very short and I was only able to see the high lights.

One of the most beautiful neighbourhoods around. This is like almost center to everything good inside Rome. These streets lead you to almost all the good places around, all the famous and must visit sites around. Apart from being close to all the monuments, there are a whole lot of restaurants and cafes around. Some are pricey while other not so much. Anyhow you get to experience the best of Rome. The cultural vibe you get around from these corners is unbeatable.
skip the line. wonderful area but if you intend to do the Clloseum or Vatican museum make sure you book your tickets on line before you go and you can walk almost right intoi both without queueing.

lively and fun. i loved its cobbled alleys and streets. This part of the town is in way to almost everything spectacular with Rome. Apart from good crowd and atmosphere, this is also the best place for you go shopping or dining as well. If for nothing then strolling through these alleys is fun in itself. Just stay away from the vendors who try to force sell cheap stuffs

The perfect place to get lost and give up the guide book. This is the perfect place put away the guide book and simply wander around letting yourself get lost and soaking up the atmosphere. It is a bit like the gothic quarter in barcelona but larger and with more history than you can take in. Our favourite bit was the market and piazzas around Fiori, especially the pizza and cakes at Forno on the corner of that piazza, to die for. You should set aside at least a couple of days for this area alone, but be prepared for tired feet, and some expensive meals - lonely planet guide was helpful in keeping the cost down!
Amazing. Fantastic place to visit. You will need more than one day there. A lot of historical places situated in close proximity to one another.

A very beautiful and romantic place. After living in this area for 3 months now, I am still amazed of the beauty and greatness it has to offer. I came to Rome to study Italian and am almost halfway there, and this is the right area to do it. The people are warm and friendly, the food and wine is delicious and the culture... is just beautiful. The biggest advice I can give to anyone is to just skip all the commercial places, like the restaurants where they stand outside to lure you in, and just ask one of the locals what is the best place to eat here. There are many small, hidden restaurants that offer authentic quality food at very cheap prices. And most of the important monuments are for free. You can walk around for hours here and keep discovering new things. Avoid the dark Pakistani men that try to sell you crappy stuff: for example the selfie-stick is made for only 2 euro's and they try to sell it for 20. Avoid commercial restaurants around important places where they try to lure you in, such as Piazza Navona and the Pantheon: prices are too high and the quality is very bad. The locals here are very warm and friendly and will help you out with anything. Don't hesitate to ask. Enjoy your stay in Rome.
bad tourist, bad restaurants.... There are lots of dirty and rubish anywhere, It's not a easy city for disabled people. You only can find pizza and pasta places.

How many places on earth have this much history in so little space?. You need a week to even come close to absorbing the history of ancient Rome. And you still won't get it all. You'll still be at the Cliff's Notes level. Get a hotel room near the Spanish Steps and plan to spend a lot of time walking around ancient Rome for at least 5 days. Get really immersed and you will come out of the experience with a new appreciation for Rome and its history. As to the answer to the question - yes there are a few other places in the world, but not many...

What an amazing district in the eternal city. From the Spanish steps to the trevi fountain (warning currently void of water for restoration for some time) this palatial district certainly impresses. Walk around and soak up the atmosphere.
SKIP LINE in vatican Museum. Instead of paying the regular price of 20 euros, with 15 euros more we could skip the line and saved at least 2.5-3 hours on the queue

Another era!. The center is amazing. With many attractions, bars and restaurants you will find for shure what to do. There are also a lot of people wearing strange clothes or costumes, and you can pay them to do a picture with you.

So many centuries of history in one small place. Centro Storico with all its yellowish colors is a splendid place to be reminded of the history of Rome - from the Spanish steps with Caffé Greco, where you find Hans Christian Andersens drawings and much more to the Jewish quarter where you should try Carciofo di Giuidia.
A must. Rome is one of Europe's most wonderful cities, and if it is a first visit in particular, this is a must.

A huge history concentration. It's impossible not to be amazed by this high historical concentration since everything you had ever studied in your life is here for you to admire! Enjoy History before your eyes!

Semplicemente bello. If you go in Rome, you should find a few hours to see the historical center. Is a beautiful combination of ancient with neoclassic and baroque. I fell in love with Rome, hope Fontana di Trevi will bring me back
Amazing City. I loved the way Italians have preserved their ancient history in terms of buildings, statues etc. and they way the combine the old with the new.

Walk around - get lost. Rome historic center is full of amazing small shops, landmarks and sights - around every corner there is a new surprise. take time to walk around and don't worry about getting lost - that's the whole point :)

evrything is to be seen. wherever your eyes could see, all is beautifull!
time is out in this place.
You travell through time from ante JC to XVII
wonderfull
A must. A must for all travelers. Eat your lunch, since there are just a few restaurants open until 18:30. Springtime is the best.

the city centre is a museum. i loved it. just walking around and admiring the magnitude of this city is a tremendous experience. all the statues lying around, or finding small piazzas with fountains is just walking in another era. the best thing for me is just walking around and discovering on your own small amazing things to admire. the centro storico i a must see in rome. take a map and try to figure out all the small gems of the city. you wont regret it.
fine. just great to hang around, visit all the nice churches en ogther buildings. it's really worth it! its all so historical meaningfull!

Great to lose yourself for a few hours. We had a great time exploring some of the backstreets away from the main sights. It's well worth doing as you'll stumble upon quaint churches and squares, and it's fun having some time without a set agenda.
wonderful. easy to find ,many shops and restaurants,we enjoyed to walk in the old streets,amazing piazza and to find the real feeling of Roma

Don't forget the city itself!. So many tourists are so caught up in all the "must-see" sites, and while those are important, don't forget to just roam around soaking in everything about the city itself: the culture, history, architecture, people, GELATO, food, etc. I was lucky enough to study in Rome for four months in the center of centro storico and that is one of the best memories from the experience. Just being in the middle of it all every day. Don't take it for granted and don't overestimate the joy you could get from walking in a place like Rome!
Lose yourselves.. Just wander around the area, poke down the alleys, following the map you will still get lost but you may find a delightful restaurant or shop, a cafe or a historic building.
Loose yourself. Just walk down the various side streets and browse through shop windows there are so many little squares to find each with statues and fountains
Rome. What more can you say apart from its Rome? With the picturesque landscapes and the history which dates back thousands of years it is the place to go!

It's ROME. The Eternal CIty... Culture, Civilization, History,... it's all here. Rome is a city to be cherished and enjoyed at a slow pace. Tourists usually miss the subtle nuances of the city and it's magic.

All the ancient history right at your feet. There is so much history in Centro Storico that you don't have to venture very far to continuously stumble upon the "next" site!! Put on your walking shoes and go!

A different feel to Rome. If you are tired of going in and out of churches in Rome, then try roaming around these narrow alleys of centro storico . These are a good experience and a bit different to the usual tourist path. The streets are filled with houses and buildings of traditional architectural and are pretty impressive especially if you look architecture. The only trouble is that these are not exactly the cleanest neighborhood
Absolute must!. When in Rome you´ll regret if you don´t walk in the old parts of Roma and take in the landmarks, buildings and so on.
POETHIC. Rome is all amazing, with attactions in each block. Storic center is an example. It is necessary to dedicate some hours to decovery it.
wonderful. it is full of ancient history, a charming city with important monuments, good and simpatic people.....nightbars ...piazza di spagna...fontana di trevi...

Huge monument and museums. We visited here in October 2013. Dominating the skyline is the mammoth Vittorio Emanuel II monument made of white marble, begun in honour of Vittorio Emanuele II, Italy's first king. This building holds the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier so no-one is allowed to sit on the monument. At the back of the building is a glass lift for which you pay to take you to the top for spectacular views over Rome. I suggest you do this closer to closing time when you can get views of the sun setting and the lights of Rome. Nearby is Palazzo Venezia where Mussolini had his official residence and made speeches from the balcony. Inside is housed an eclectic collection of paintings, jewellery, tapestries etc. Just north of the Piazza Venezia is Palazzo Doria Pamphilj housing the Galleria Doria Pamphilj. This is a very undervisited museum and it still belongs to the Pamphilj family today. It is a must see for this museum and you can take photos by paying an extra E5 camera fee which was worth paying.

Rome between History and abandon. We enjoyed our stay in Rome for 5 days, and loved visiting the historical centre and all the important museums and places Rome has to offer. I was a little bit disappointed by the not so clean streets, building full of graffiti and unpicked rubbish. I strongly believe that the authorities should show a greater interest in maintaining the city clean, it can be a barrier in actually getting the feel of the city.
Great walking area. Love walking around this old part of Rome, narrow streets and alleys, great places to have a drink , cup of coffee or a snack. Never get tired of ambling around here.

Get lost and re-discover yourself. Besides the Colosseum, walking the narrow streets that empty unexpectedly into piazzas dedicated to saints and boasting neighborhood eateries and bars, is a 24 hour experience that will allow you the time to appreciate the past, both yours and Rome's. Nostalgia is bound to hit you as you appreciate the way Romans lived (and live today). All of the neighborhoods have something different to offer and you are never far from the east/west corridor leading from the Spanish Steps to the Piazza Navona or the north/south shopping corridor of the Via Corso leading from the Piazza del Popolo to the Piazza Venezia.

I liked it a lot. Taking a walk there means taking a walk to find out everything about that city. Historical buildings, beautiful roads full of people, a lot of street sellers and so on. It is amazing and what I really liked are people on the streets who are singing and playing instruments. Italy is special, but Rome and streets like those are amazing!

Everything you need to see!. Wonderful part of Rome where you have all the famous landmarks, small alleys and some really good restaurants. Can walk here for days and still see new things. Best not to have a plan but just stroll around.
Wonderful!. It felt like every inch was full of history. Very well preserved and maintained. Lots of restaurants and shops. I wish I had stayed in Rome longer....

Feet from the Vatican. Turn left instead of walking down the main road from the Vatican and enter into this intimate, authentic neighbourhood. As with everywhere in the world that depends on tourists, people standing desperately outside of their restaurants can be tedious, but the smaller places at the other end of the road from the Vatican are cheaper and sweeter.The religious vestments shops are an education, the colourwashed buildings, narrow streets and ordinary people taking their rubbish out, the homely feel of the place is very comfortable.

Authentic shops. I would pick this location not only to enjoy the spirit of Rome, but also one of great locations to shop if you're actually interested in buying something original and authentic and not the chain brand stuff. Great cafes and ice cream parlours too!
walk in the history of Rome. When you go to rome, you see the history written on the stones...I am in Love with Rome's Center.. Romantic place.. you should visit it
All in one. Beautiful place with lots of shops, restaurants and history. One not to be missed and by foot of course.

Gorgeous place to amble around. This is a beautiful part of Rome, providing lots to see simply by walking about. The architecture is really beautiful and of course there are lots of places to stop for a drink or a nibble....
Open Air Museum. If you like history, this is the place to go. I have been to Rome many times and I still discover new places and things
Beautiful Rome!. My only regret was that we've stayed just for 3 nights. Not enough to really experience everything! Planned the next visit already lol

Get Lost. I mean it - go without any plan or map and get lost. This is one of the most interesting and beautiful cities anywhere. You will see fantastic sights, beautiful people. Take it easy and stroll.

Who needs transport, just walk and ponder. The centre of Rome, filled with alleys opening onto piazza after piazza, some with well known significance, others left to your own imagination. You could spend weeks just strolling the streets, bumping into monuments and temples, a must visit and highly recommended as a staging point for first time Rome visitors.
A lot of history.. The emperor's palaces, ancient cathedrals, tumbs, theatres, saunas and thermes. You are immersed in a visit to the past.
Open Air Museum. So much to see, most of it free (Pantheon, churches, fountains, temples, obelisks, statues, plazas, facades, architecture, etc). You could spend a lifetime here and not see it all.
An outdoor museum - Love Rome!!. Start in Piazza de Popolo and have a relaxed stroll in the Centro Storico for the next two days. Loved Rome!!!

The heart of Rome (civilisation & la bella vita). This should be Rome's first stop
If that's your first time in Rome, i suggest to go with some public transport close by the area and get lost into centro storico.
Than add to the tour the Hop-On-Hop-Off bus tour and a walking tour to Trastevere zone.

Centro Storico. The Centro Storico is fascinating! It's like going back in time 2,000 years! The Coliseum, the ruins of what was the center of the old Roman Empire, the magnificent columns still standing after so many centuries...It's incredible!

Simply wander. The best way and only way to see the Centro Storico is on foot. Stroll through the narrow streets, look up and admire the buildings around you since the magnificent architecture never fails to impress. Wander in and out of churches since often the most unassuming building has the most spectacular interior. My favourite route on foot takes me from Castel St. Angelo, across the river and through the narrow streets to Piazza Navona and from there to the Pantheon and finally to the Trevi Fountain. A good walk but well worth the effort.

I could stroll for days..... Centro storico is absolutely magical, especially in the evenings. It is a must-see, and I recommend finding a hotel in this area if possible. It was fabulous to step out of our hotel and be smack-dab in the center of Rome's history. The lighting in the alleys is a dream for photographers, with a new photo opportunity around every corner. Piazza Navona and the Pantheon were our favourites and we never felt unsafe in this area, even at night.

go sightseeing!. My husband and I decided to tour France and Italy for our 3 week honeymoon in late August. One word describes my honeymoon...Amazing!!! There is so much culture, history and breathtaking art to take in...3 weeks just wasn't enough time..so we're planning another trip back! Sightseeing throughout Rome takes a bit of walking around by foot, so start your days early and make sure you wear very comfy shoes and DO NOT forget your camera and your bottle of chilled water,...bring an umbrella if you go during the warmer months...the sun's a killer.

Architecture roman style.. Simply a pleasure to stroll around these wonderful shop and restuarant lined streets. Only downside is the amount of beggars and bangladeshie street traders, i will be suprised if there are any left in there own country. Would have been 5 stars except for the hassling

Joyful!!. You cannot be in Rome and not stroll down the narrow streets and alleys taking you from Piazza Navona to Piazza della rotonda to Fontana di Trevi. You can sit in a Cafe in one of the piazzas or have a nice dinner in a restaurant or just enjoy a gelato on the go. This whole area is fun and whatever you do there will make you happy. Just be careful with your belongings as there are pick pockets in crowded places.

Centro Strrico. Was in an apartment complex. Very quiet neighborhood. Price was fair. Room was okay, and more like a bed and breakfast.. Clean.. Could have had mor than packaged danish for the free continental breakfast, but overall good value! Very nice place to be
Nice. Nice, we've seen before. Liked the Fontana de Trevi. Nice historic city. We've liked it very much. We preference this city upon another cities in Europe.

at least a week!. You'll need at least a whole week: tons of monuments, landscapes and point of interest to view. Obviously don't miss the opportunity to loose yourself rounding every corner you find interesting (but don't forget a map!). You'll see ancient fountains, columns, locals... could be crowded if sunny. Buy a sandwich in a "Salumeria" (less than 3€), cheap and tasty.

This is my 5th visit to Rome and I'm still finding new place & people to interest me. The eternal city offers the most varied attractions from the Forum to temples & excellent hidden away places to eat and drink.
walking in the centro storico. Wonderful to just walk and gawk, sit and have a latte.... even it rather grey weather, it was very enjoyable.

A great part of the city.. The streets of the Centro Storico are just wonderful You can feel the history all around. But it's alive, not like a dusty exhibit! Round every corner there's a wonderful surprise. It's lively at night. We went in Septenber and it was lovely.
Too many people,crowded.. The spots is not perfect as imaged.But did worth seeing.Compare to the Trevi or Nuovana,some great church are amazing and free!
definetely historical. I liked the restaurants and the roman forum. i have been at the jewish Ghetto Via del portico d'ottavia, I ate at a great fast food better known as Shilo

Wonderful place to meander. To help clarify exactly where this is I copy the following from Wikipedia:[this is] The historic center of Rome enclosed within the Aurelian walls (to the left of the Tiber ) and Gianicolensi walls (to the right of the river) has been recognized in 1980 , World Heritage Site by ' UNESCO . The entire historic city recognizes the value of more than 25,000 points of interest Most of the top attractions in Rome, excluding those on the left side of the river (Vatican side).The real heart in my opinion are the narrow winding streets which abound and are so enjoyable to meander down, attractions speak for themselves and are reviewed separately. You can easily spend a couple of days doing this, and I suggest you do (if time allows).

Make sure you have plenty of time and energy for the Colosseum complex. There are places to see in every corner. Reserve plenty of time to see the Colosseum/Forum/Palatine, it is worth the walk but make sure you have snacks in the purse. Get as many audio guides on your ipod as you can, things don't have a lot of explanation when you get there.
so much to see. bit crowded, but the pope was there. we had lovely weather and we ate out it restaurants ate lemon ice cream did it all

rabbit warren. Nothing there, just a rabbit warren of endless streets that all look the same. Everywhere you look is some crappy Italian restaurant or snack bar, very hard to find proper shops, just designer rubbish.

Very nice and interesting sightseeing. We enjoyed to walk on the streets and to see as much as we could. I recommend Piazza Navona, Roman Forum, Fontana di Trevi, Roman Column, Constantine Arch, and so many others...

Round the forum. I've been to Rome millions of times, but this time didn't fancy any museums and art galleries, so spent the morning walking round Via dei Fori Imperiali. Didn't go INSIDE because the weather was uncertain and didn't want to risk paying only to have to run back home after ten minutes. Stayed outside looking in with a guidebook in hand. Amazing to see the curia where the senate used to meet, (not where Caesar was killed though, it's another curia). An extra was the church of Saints Cosmas and Damian, with a glass west wall. As you look down from it, you're looking into a real Pagan Roman temple! Then up the hill to the Aracoeli church, so magnificent and strangely different from other Roman churches - then onto the terrace of the Altare della Patria where there's a lovely rooftop café bistro. Fabulous views and a feeling of being somewhere special!

Around every corner is a surprise. Return visits can be disappointing, but not to Rome, where each walk and around every corner is a surprise waiting to be discovered. From cats to churches, temples and fountains - I could walk around all day.
Go off the main streets for better shopping. For lovely leather goods in a large range of styles and coliours and actually made in Rome seek out Ibez - Atrigianato in Cuoio (Via dei Chiavari 39).

If you want to live and breathe "Rome" you have to go for a walk through this area!. If you want to live and breathe "Rome" you have to go for a walk through this area, you can see anything, restaurants with diferent range of prices, gifts shops, art, fountain, architecture, churches, and so on through many long and short streets. Try visiting it at day and at night, it's almost two differente places!Really worth it! Visited March 2013

Lovely place for a stroll. We spent some time walking around here, stopping for lunch and buying glass Xmas decorations from one of the little shops. There are many expensive restaurants and the more modestly priced are more expensive than we found in other sections of the city, but then its such a nice place to sit outside for lunch those few euros could be considered a fair price, stay away from the restaurants in the larger squares though. The buildings and atmosphere cost nothing to take in, though I defy anyone to resist the gelato shops for long!

Very atmospheric. The whole area is very interesting, but the highlight for us was Piazza Navona, which has some interesting buildings and statues.However, we would recommend looking for a restaurant in one of the nearby side-streets.
So unique. There is not one place in the centro storico that is not worth a visit. Only walking can make it interesting.

A Must Neighborhood. There is not metro service to this neighborhood, but many busses and the No. 8 tram will get you close. Aside from the Pantheon, Piazza Navona and Campo dei Fiore, check out the Palazzo Farnese, which recently started offering tours of its elegant building and gardens. It must be booked ahead online, and there are not many tours, so plan ahead. Also, stroll down the Via Giulia, one of Rome's prettiest streets any time of the day. You don't have to stay in this neighborhood, as it is quite touristed. It is a 20 to 30-minute walk from Trastevere, Via Veneto and the Spanish Steps.

Wandering heaven. You'll always find something new in this area. Don't be afraid of going into any of the churches, they're usually free and many of them are full of priceless art that you'd have to pay to see in a museum.

So much to do and see. The Kolbe Hotel staff were helpful in orienting you and giving direction to this area. They separated the area into four main areas - the colosseum and Palatine Hill; the shopping area with Trevi Fountain and Spanish Steps with Piazza Poppolo; the Pantheon and Campo del Fiori market and Piazza Navona; the Vatican. All walkable from the hotel.
a short Roman holiday trip. Public transport not alaways easy because of Being Rome an ancient city. For the same reason Rome has a sample of every age of human civilization.

Fascinating. It's incredible! It seems you came back in time and have the opportunity to admire all those ruins. The Colosseum is amazing! Once you're there you think you're in a movie. The Roman Forum is a spatacle!

Cobbled streets with lots to see. The Centro Storico area of Rome is amazing. It's exceeded our expectations for the historic area of the city.There appears to be endless cobbled streets, some bustling, some quiet, with lots of cafes and restaurants to stop off at, sample the culture, eat Gelato and take in the ambience of Rome.It's very easy to get lost in Rome, but go with the flow, round every corner there is something to see! Don't miss the Pantheon, allow time for simply sitting with a coffee and people watching. Be careful on the streets as they are narrow and the Italians drive quiet fast down them. Lots of picture opportunities, have the camera ready!

Italia...........interesting !. Easy to get around, and loads to things to see,the historic centre of Rome is small, but unbelievably packed with nice places to see.. small streets, churches, fountains!! It's exactly like from the movies.
Interesting to wander around. Don't miss the main square with its 3 fountains - piazza navona. Also the Pantheon is amazing and free!

Great to walk through the city center! Every great ruin is near one another via walking distance.. The bus stops show bus-connections that does not exist.. or if there is any timetable available, they are not followed (we lost 45 min waiting for a bus whoch never came)!!!Besides, Our OWN booked BUS TRIP, operated by Bus "Open 110" changed their driving plan without any advice or signalization.. there we lost once again 1 hours waiting for a bus which should stop there every 15 minutes!!Fortunately we asked around, and some people saw our bus parked somewhere around the corner, where we could catch it and proceed our "Hop-On/Hop-Off" city tour.

Good for a stroll. Centro Storico contains acres of ancient Roman remains and fabulous renaissance churches surrounded by mad Roman traffic. Bars, cafes and restaurants are plentiful allowing some great opportunities for people-watching.
old and beautiful. Liked everything. What's not to like? Could be cleaner, but it's OK. We have spent 7 days just in Rome, and that was not enought to see everything we planned. The city is amaizing!
Ancient History with modern people. A place where history meets beauty and modern people meet history.. Great experience, must see place

Amazing...watch out for cars though. So many incredible things to see. You can sped days walking around and seeing ancient ruins nestled beside 16th century buildings etc. The streets are narrow and cars go by fast and close so watch out!
old and wonderful. i loved the old buildings and the way that it makes you feel like nothing hos chainged over the last 1000 years, and all the old building that are under ground wow!!!
Pretty... busy!. A very pretty part of Rome, and of course the oldest, but jam packed with tourists which diluted the experience somewhat.
beauteful. pantheon, piazza di Spagna,campidoglio vatican city with the amazing Sistine Chappel, restaurants and boutiques

The center still has its lovely corners.... The Centro Storico is largely overcome by tourists anywhere you go nowadays; there is almost no "low season" anymore when it comes to the Centro. But it is a large area, and there are still many lovely corners to be seen which are not overwhelmed by folks staring at maps and wondering where they are. Obviously, the best times to see it are off hours---very early in the morning, after 5PM when many are exhausted, Sunday mornings (although much is closed). The big outdoor piazze with fountains (Navona, Fontana Trevi) get better in the evening, and very late at night is often the best time to see them.

Plan to get disoriented as you explore the alleys. Plan to get disoriented as you explore the alleyways of the Centro Storico. Just walk and wander, stop for a glass of wine or simply enjoy the gelato. The she's and workshops are interesting. Eventually you will discover a familiar street or plaza. Or if necessary stop a taxi and take it back to your hotel.Word of advice, always carry a business card from your hotel.

Try it... you might like it. This was a 1 week trip with an accomodation at "Ground Zero". My last 3 days, I left my b&b, roaming "Centro Storico" WITHOUT A MAP ! I just wandered wherever the wind blew me. Only in Rome does this work, as there isn't a block you'll walk where SOMETHING doesn't catch your interest (even if it's not listed in your guidebook). Was I ever lost ?... Constantly/Never (as you're only lost if you care). Wherever I was, eventually I'd see an iconic sign that would give me my bearings. This isn't for everyone, but I will attest - It was a treat to meander the street without the frustration of constantly trying to find myself on a map. Now, about the bus system....
Don't miss Centro Storico. Especially don't miss the Blue Ice gelato!!! Worth the trip. Seriously, the ruins, the remains, the blending of old and new is a sight to see.

Is there a more beautiful and interesting city centre anywhere?. The historic centre of Rome is small, but unbelievably packed with beautiful, interesting and wonderful things to see.Stand at the Pantheon for example and within 2 kilometres in each direction are dozens of unique attractions like the Colosseum, the Galleria Borghese, the Vatican and many others, charming, narrow, twisting cobbled streets, great restaurants and coffee shops, beautiful squares and parks and lovely shops. Every spot seems to contain something of interest to see - a statue, a church, a museum, a fountain, a column or obelisk, an ancient ruin, the river Tiber, or an interesting shop or bar, or even just the passing crowds. The colours of the buildings in the historic centre are also wonderful, lots of faded reds, yellows and pinks. They are greatly uplifting on a sunny, blue-sky day as do the unusual Roman pine trees.The whole of the historic centre can reasily be reached on foot, by metro or by bus or taxi. If you can, by foot is the best way. The metro is very easy to use as it only has 2 lines which cross Rome in an X shape with the intersection at Termini main train station. One arm of the X runs from south-west Rome, up past the Colosseum and on towards north-east Rome. The other runs from the direction of the Vatican down towards south-east Rome.Do consider getting a Roma pass for 30 euro before you go to Rome as this gives you free entry to your first 2 attractions, half-price to many more, plus it allows you to skip the ticket line which can be a real boon. The Roma pass also gives you 3 days free transport on the metro and buses. The Roma pass is very easy to use on the metro - you just press you Roma card on the ticket barriers and they open for you.The buses is Rome are also surprisingly easy to use and cover more of the historic centre than the metro.Also, it is worth considering getting a rental flat if you plan on being in Rome for a week or so. You can get some very nice central Rome flats for much less than a hotel room and getting a bit of food in for breakfast is very easy.All in all, if you have any interest in art, shopping, good food and wine, history, architecture, sculpture, and more, then you should make visiting Rome a priority.
Full of Character. This is totally full of character and charm and a wonderful place to visit. Easy to get around, and loads to things to see, amazing place.

Shorter in the map. When you start to point out places to see on Google mapm in Rome it looks easy and a quick stroll. But don´t kid yourself, there is alot to see in the Historic Center of Rome. I was in a hotel a few blocks from the train station and already went into got into the more then sixty years if you understand...so walking is a pleasure looking up and around but it can kill your back and legs if you don´t schedule a two or three day tour at the Centro. It´s worth every corner but my back & legs don´t agree....
Must go. Amazing place. Very nice, love it. A lot to visit. The perfect is make a car tour, so you can have a whole idea of rome.
