the living museum. you can find the most amazing artisans tucked down little side streets who proudly practice their craft like they have for generations.

huge!. I think it's possible to spend a week in rome and not see everything. but if you only have a weekend you can do most of the sights plus the vatican, but not much time to go in the buildings or museums. you'll walk for hours and try to see as much as possible but at 18hrs you'll need a little siesta to recover!

Wonderful city!. This eternal city is amazing in every sense of the way. It's one big historical pearl and it's absolute must! so many beautiful piazzas, small streets, churches, fountains!! It's exactly like from the movies. Loved it very much!

Let the charm of Rome surround you. Loved looking at the little shops and trying one of many restaurants, pastry shops and gelaterias hidden away in the streets of Centro Storico. You can find yourself mixed in with locals and able to take in the "real" Rome!
Nice. Lovely to stroll around and absorb the culture. Around every corner seems to be a delightful blast of history, or hidden gem of a church holding some ancient relic. An absolute must.

Rome is resting on its laurels. Rome has some of the most amazing collection of antiquities on the planet - buildings, sculpture, ruins, you name it, much of it open to the public free of charge (although yes, elsewhere charges and queues can also be exorbitant).I have given it 1* not because of the sites themselves, which are 5* amazing, but because of the slack attitude of the authorities in terms of how they treat and welcome tourists. From the moment you land in the (grotty and outdated) airport and are directed towards the under-resourced and under-friendly "tourist" information there, the city itself does little to welcome and give real structure to tourism - initiatives are mostly in the hands of a few hotels and tour guides.Bathroom facilities around the sites are dirty and inadequate (and sometimes ask you to pay for the privilege nonetheless!), and not enough has been done to promote accessibility for those with movement difficulties. That goes for the public transport and the narrow pavements too.The free maps are also pretty bad (ok so you can buy better ones, but I have also seen more effort made at producing decent maps and brochures in other cities).On the plus side, public transport is cheap (apart from taxis, which are ridiculous - we paid anything between Eur 12 and Eur 25 for the same distance), but the Metro is limited in scope.I laughed out loud when I heard Rome was thinking of bidding for the 2020 Olympics - thank goodness that has been shelved, the city's ageing infrastructure can barely cope with the tourists as is.In short, the sites of Rome are amazing, the city of Rome in terms of its infrastructure and attitude to tourism, is not.

too crowded,,,,too cold. masses of tourists everywhere....and bitter cold. great shopping possibilities...leather bags and prime brands at bargain prices. will come back in summer.was just too cold...even for making a phone call :)
Beautiful Piazzas!. Lots of beautiful piazzas. Definitely visit as much as you can walk. Must visit Piazza Navona and Pantheon.

Wonder at every corner. Just wander through the narrow alleys , view the shops and sights , take in the markets and squares. This si where to find the value lunches with home-made pasta!BUT- stand for a coffee and piece of pizza in the cafe bars, the locals would never sit down ( up to 5 times the price!- BE Warned!!)

It is the Eternal City. There is just so much History in rome it's difficult to know where to start. the key sites are the Vatican, the Pantheon, Trevi Fountain, Capitol and the Forum / Palatine / Colloseum. For the latter here's a quick tip. You can buy a combined entry ticket for the Forum, Palatine and Capitol (valid two days). Cost (Feb 2013) is 12 Euro but free to over 65 (take id though). Buy your ticket at the Ticket Office for the forum - that way you can sil past the long queues at the Colloseum and walk right in!

Yes yes, it IS a must see indeed. Liked the historic buildings. Disliked the not-so-nice fellow tourists, commercial mumbo jumbo, street artists. But then again, can't avoid these when you are in a world wide tourist hot spot :-)

never ending. If you like to wonder around narrow cobble stone streets discovering the delights of Rome then you'll love the Centro Storico. All of the major attractions are within easy walking distance so a voyage of self discovery is perfectly feasible. If however you want to get that little bit more out of your visit then enlist the help of on of the many guides that are around, you will not be disappointed.

Full of character for every taste. Wonderful to walk around the historic center. From the Campo di Fiori, Piazza Nabona to the Pantheon, Fontana di Trevi....If you can go into the forum with a good guide. They bring alive the times of Caesar and Augustus. Where they lived, how they worked, where and how they met. Fantastic to be in the middle of so much history.

The best old buildings I've ever seen and the shopping there is great. The streets are clean, the buildings are old and Gorgeous, you will really enjoy your walk, if you want shopping this place will be very good choice for you, a lot of designer stores on the street infront of the spanish steps in addition to local stores and international brands.
History coming alive. What can I say, it is mindblowing to walk in the ruins of ancient Rome and see them still standing there next to the modern Rome... all withing walking distance.

This is why you came. The central old area of Rome is clearly a must and it is utterly charming and offers everything from small cafes to the fanciest stores on cobblestone streets. As important a site as any in Rome. Enjoy getting lost.
very nice place. center is ok to sleep in rome really cozy. you can avoid to take any public transportation. i like rome city center at all
Rome...a great City. It is beautiful and very interesting, I have visited on other occassions not just on this trip. It is just great!

Better than anticipated. My wife and I just spent the month of January in a lovely rental apartment in the via Veneto neighborhood. I'd always had misgivings about spending time in Rome. Many reviews have made it sound like it's populated solely by annoying tourists and local pickpockets. We're not really interested in old works of art, especially of a religious nature. We rarely attend museums. I don't like to wait in lines and absolutely hate feeling like I'm spending money foolishly. But refusing to yield to my wife's wishes comes with a heavy penalty. So Roma it was.What a delightful surprise this City was. Granted, it's undoubtedly a different experience in January than July. But the people were friendly and polite. We never once felt threatened or at risk of being robbed. In fact, we can't recall anyone being even a bit rude to us in an entire month. This is a walker's paradise. We averaged at least 5 hours out on the sidewalks each day and never once had a boring stroll. When people say there are surprises around every corner they mean it literally. On both macro and micro levels the city is fascinating. Seeing remnants of 2000 year old buildings doesn't just happen at the sites you read about- any block may have its hidden treasures. There's always something interesting to see. And spending a lot of money while you're doing it isn't necessary. Public transportation is cheap and accessible. Good meals can be found everywhere at prices that are cheap compared to cities such as New York or London. The society is pretty relaxed. Drinking wine or beer while having a panino in a public piazza or park is commonplace. While we'd heard that there's been an upsurge in illicit drug use we only smelled marijuana twice in a month and were never approached by drug dealers.The food was memorable. Everyone finds their favorite pizzerias and neighborhood restaurants but the quality of the markets makes cooking at home a great option too. Eating well is just an integral part of life here. Italian is not an easy language to learn. Knowing a bit of French or Spanish may help a little but it also complicates things. Fortunately, a lot of people speak at least some English and the ones that don't generally seem pretty good-humored about communicating via gestures and a few mispronounced words from either language. Listening to natives speak Italian to each other is a different matter. It's such a pretty and expressive language to the ear- which may help to explain why people seem to be talking constantly. Watching the way hand gestures are incorporated into the message was fun too. Even when people were talking on cell phones the free hand had to be moving at all times. Face to face it was like a ballet for the hands.A person could easily stay in the outer areas of Rome, spend 35 euros for a month's transit pass, and just ride into the old part of town every day to see the sites. It's an attractive and potentially inexpensive option. But there really is something special about staying in the historic center of the City. As much as it hurts to say this, my wife was right about staying in Rome...

A living history. Brilliant. It's never boring walking these cobblestone streets, no matter what time of the day or night. During the day there are clothes stores, tratoria's, bars and grocery stores. At night are the restaurants and the Roman version of pubs. Never a dull moment.

Come stay and explore. Easy to reach from all areas of Rome. If you enjoy people watching this is the place to go. Find a bench and enjoy the view. Many pleasant and friendly people that enjoy sharing their experiences. Truly a must visit. Trasportation by bus or taxi is always easy to find.
You have to stay there!. Roman historical centre is really amazing. Is full of little stree, they call it vicoli and you can walk in that street looking always something new! Choose your hotel there

Just wander around and stop at a few bars. There is so much to see and the Centro Storico is such a mix of ancient and modern with surprises around every corner. The main sights were busy so hard to get photos without lots of people in them - but we found some great bars and quiet piazzas as well.

Just get lost. It's incredible, time traveling. Surprises and beauties in every corner, every street. Iwould 100% getting lost and don't follow straight directions to get to somewhere, let yourself inmerse in the ancient world of antique Rome. The pace, the smells of pastry, pizza and pasta, the stores, the little streets that take you to incredible places, like a hidden forum that became a public park ... and then the Tevere River. Oh Rome
FIN ROMAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA. is no way there is to much to see where you go you will see new places fontana di trevi,piazza di spagna colosseo and piazza venezia we love rome our second home
atmospheric.... Although i believe that the whole city is a museum, the core is the Centro Storico.Very nice atmosphere and classy surroundings, and people. A very nice walk to have
beatiful city. all central area is very interesting .... all city' center is an archeological area..... There is so much to see that i didn't have time. The Eternal city. There is no place like Rome

Beautiful. Rome is just a beautiful and amazing city. It is unlike anywhere else in the world where the ancient world and modern life collide. You walk around the streets and see how people lived many years ago.
walk around all the piazzas!. begin your walk early in the morning,have strength and patience to walk around all piazzas and small streets.

La Bella Roma. If you're going to Rome, there is no where other than the Centro Storico to stay. It is the "Eternal City" and it offers everything you could hope to find. From its ancient sites to its newest restaurants and bars there is no other city on earth quite like it. No matter how much time you have to spend here, you will not run out of things to do. Don't miss the magnificent museums, the ancient buildings and sites, the piazzas, fountains, food and wine. Cafe Late at the Tazza D'Oro, Gelato at Blue Ice, Piazza Navona in the evening, Campo De' Fiori anytime. Shop till you drop on Via Condotti. Central Rome has it all. Beware, it is noisy, a bit dirty and congested with traffic, but it is the real thing.

amazing. It is great to know a place so old you thing it is not true. It drives you again to history classes at school. The constructions so old and yet there... it's not to miss in a lifetime.... But you have to go early, because it is a lot to see... and the lines are long.

This is Rome. Glorious, wonderful, crowded etc. Try and book your hotel in the "old city" (Centro Storico) so that everything is in walking distance of your hotel (we used the Hotel Smeraldo - perfectly fine.Save some energy for walking around at night - the illumination is of course glorious - the fountains, piazzas, restaurants of all price categories - sit in a piazza, eat, drink and "be part" of Rome.

SPQR. The Eternal Rome. There really is no place like Rome. History is in the air that you breathe, in the cobbled streets you walk on and the grand buildings that surround you. Then you look again and see the the black dirt on every surface, the cigarette butts between every cobbled stone and the trash lying outside the big bins. SPQR (Sono Porci Questi Romani) Google the translation of this because it is very true. This beautiful city is covered in trash. There is rubbish all over the place. There aren't enough carparks so people park on every curb and on any free area that can be found. If you are in a wheelchair, good luck! Rome is certainly not catered for you. And then you think, ah well it's ok, every urbanised large city is dirty, at least I can have some amazing food & wine here. How disappointed was I. We had a few meals in the city and the customer service was some of the worst I had ever experienced and the food was even worse. Please whatever you decide to do, do not eat in central Rome, not only it isn't authentic but you are also paying twice or three times more than what you would outside of the city centre. And then you stumble upon the Fountain of Trevi, Il Vittoriano, il Collosseo, Piazza Di Spagna, Piazza del Popolo, Trastevere, Piazza Navona and suddenly you forget the dirt, the rudeness and the bad food (+the fact that you have to pay 50 cents every time you need the loo and they are so dirty I might add)For all its flaws there really is no place like Rome. Rome sweet home.
Too much to do. There is SO much to see that we didn't have time. But it was fantastic to be able to get amongst the ruins of ancient Rome and imagine what it was like.

Astonishing. I was always sceptic about travelling to Rome, as it was so obvious tourist attraction that gave us the reason to delay our visit there. That was a big mistake - we should have been there much earlier. Centro Storico is (as name says) overflowing with history, with baroque architecture accompanying ancient one, you could find a historic monument on every corner. Plus countess cafes and restaurants (although in the Colloseo neighbourhoud - via Cavur, via Penispera - I belive they offfer better prices). A must visit site.
interesting area. all central area is very interesting, with different type of museum, archeological sites, shops and much more...All city' center is an archeological area.....

Visit in winter to avoid too many tourists. Cobbled streets & narrow alleyways leading to less famous but breathtaking piazzas. Incredible buildings with beautiful decor & architecture. A surprise around every corner. Just wander around, soak up the atmosphere of ancient times and marvel at the beauty of it all. Easy to get lost even with a map but this is part of the pleasure as you accidentally discover hidden piazzas, tiny cafes and bars. All around is ancient history that you can see, touch and feel. An absolute pleasure.
Beautiful!!!!!!!!!. The history of Rome is fantastic. A lot to see. The monuments are beautiful, but they should take care of them. It's a city to see once in your life
magic. a big center,to visit walking... every single meter is beatiful!!! breathtakig! absolutely a wonderful city!!!

The real Rome. This is why Rome is so popular. It is the classic small side roads, amazing old buildings, cobblestones, cafes and overall atmosphere. It is like going back in time and yes it is like in the movies. Wear comfy shoes, don't bother with a map and just immerse yourself in the culture and history and enjoy it!

Rome. Just these four letters should make you shiver.. How can you review the Centro Storico of Rome? Is the most history-filled place in the world, and one of the most fascinating. The biggest open-space museum.

The reason you go to Rome. This is where Rome just romances you and injects its culture and history into your arteries....the only downfall is having to leave....5 months after i was there i am still addicted. Whatever you do stay here for as long as poss and enjoy the sights by day and night.

The reason to see Rome. You could wander back in time for days and days. Really well preserved buildings. The Colosseum is so beautiful at night. I recommend walking all the way around it on the outside to see its different looks.

You've seen it in the movies....... ...and yes, it is true! Wonderfully atmospheric and small enough to get around on foot. From the Trevi Fountain to the Forum and the Colosseum with beautiful churches, the Pantheon and Piazza Navona, it's like being in a film set.

get lost and enjoy. after first attempts to follow a tour in our guide book, we ditched it and just decided to get lost. a look at the map tells you that you can't *really* get lost and land in a strange place. we tried our best but always were in the center. even just looking at the buildings, soaking up the atmosphere is awesome. do this at least one day of your journey.
A must see. You must have comfortable shoes and be prepared to walk, walk and enjoy yourself, discovering marvels at every step.

Wear good shoes!. The centro storico is lovely to wander through and explore. We visited most evenings to stroll and people watch. Make sure you wear good shoes - my feet and legs were killing me by the end of our week in Rome.

Got lost ... and that was perfect. We got a little lost in this area more than once but never felt nervous or too forlorn. We had fun going up and down alleys, sure we were just about to find the piazza or this site or that restaurant. Beautiful area to be lost with the cobblestones, alley, cafes, wine bars, restaurants, etc. Wish I was there right now!

Of course!. The Pantheon - impressive if eclectic (with its rotunda and Greek-inspired square portico!) converted-into-a-church temple dating back to the second century AD; Piazza Pavone - worth seeing bu we lost the “vue d’ensemble” of the elongated piazza with Bernini’s 3 fountains and its surrounding buildings (notably Borromini’s baroque Chiesa di Sant’ Agnese in Agone), because of the kermesse that was occupying the whole square! Campo di' Fiori; Piazza Farnese - where we had some refreshments sitting at a café of the same name, facing the beautiful and large Palazzo Farnese which now houses the French embassy.!
None To Compare. Is there any city with a historical district to compare with Rome's? There are thousands of famous, magnificent, and significant sites to visit--much of it free.
Rome is beautiful. what can i say? rome city center is the most wonderful thing that you can see in the whole world. you can spend days, weeks always wandering around there and you never get bored

It doesn't get any better. I spent a semester here and I wouldn't have wanted to go anywhere else. It's a walking museum, literally, and I would advise you lose yourself on random streets and stop to look at every detail of ancient Roman architecture. Since Rome wasn't built in a day, give yourself at least a few to explore.
Nice walks in Roma. A wonderful evening walk during the Christmas holiday. The Christmas lights are lovely and the temperature is in the 40s, so it was a great brisk stroll.

The Eternal City. If you don't make it anywhere else in Rome, this will explain why Rome is the Eternal City. Under most excavations are more excavations, there seems to be no end to the discoveries and insights into our past. In the midst of ruins that may be where Julius Caesar was stabbed, is a cat sanctuary and on seemingly every block, an eatery providing flavors that will lay dormant but very alive to be revived on your next visit. If you are not constrained by preconceived notions of creature comforts and a dislike for physical exercise, Rome will enrich your soul.

Nice walk. Take a long and slow stroll through this area and you won't have to use your tour guide book. History will just pop out in the most amazing and unexpected places. That is the amazing thing about Rome, you don't have to look hard for landmarks. Landmarks and sites are just at every corner.

Walking and gawking. Much of Roma's centro storico is pedestrian only -- or limited traffic. That makes stopping in the middle of the street to take in marvelous architecture, Christmas lights, and Romans themselves an easy, safe adventure.
Walk around and enjoy the atmosphere. Christmas fair at the Piazza Navona is nice to see, but nothing really to buy. Just walk around and enjoy!
perfect place to stroll and fantacize about the past. We found December weather perfect for seeing the centro storico. My favorite day of our two weeks in Rome was spent here.

walking through the centuries, at a peaceful pace.. There is nothing, absolutely nothing you can dislike, when the time comes to visit Rome's heart. I was living in Rome for 15 years, when a boy, Yet, every time I come back to Rome, I take my time to walk its streets, squares, cross the various Tiber's bridges. Always an unique sensation, like crossing an open sky museum, filled with everyday's joy and noise.

One day walk there. Nice combination of old and new, though we could not see all (e.g. Pantheon) during a winter day visit. It may be appropriate to restore statue of Markus Aurelius on the "Piazza de la collogna" and make another with the statue of Saint Paul on it.
Ancient Roman sites. several new museums have opened in the ancient City and many sites have had more ruins opened up. Wonderful history lessons to be had here.

The true Rome. This is quite easily my favourite part of rome, just walking the beautiful streets passing pieces of history. There are so many great thing to discover. It is almost magical walking around here at night.
Amazing place. Everywhere you turn your head there is a building or a church or a square or some artwork that takes your breath away. If you come here 10 times it won't be enough

A very heart of Rome. Construed of various historical layers one over another or one next to another. Mixture of styles, epoches, civil and religious objects, everyone will find his/ her the favourite spot. Just the very of Rome.

The Roman Village. I love the Centro Storico, which is quite small, so you can walk everywhere. The Campo d'Fiori bustles with a market in the day time, and busy nightlife later on. Elegant Piazza Navona, atmospheric Piazza della Rotonda, The Trevi Fountain (and so many more fountains) not to mention the ruins of the Forum and the colosseum.

What a feast for the eyes and soul!. There is no other city like Rome, or ever was, or ever can be. Rome has been an urban center for more than 2,000 years, it's a place where layers of history, civilization and life unfold right before your eyes. It's was the first city to reach a population of 1 million in 5 B.C. History, culture, art and mystery abound everywhere you look. Rome has more than 900 churches, many of them are masterpieces, hundreds of squares with spectacular fountains, archeological sites that stand to witness to the city's past glory, museums that hold world's greatest art treasures... Rome is a city with many faces, where ancient, medieval and modern stand next to each other.  I visited Rome at least 20 times, and every month I go there I have immense childish enthusiasm knowing I'll be embarking on e new adventure, discovering the Rome's many sites that always offer something new: experience, emotions, stories, mysteries, the human genius...  I will be eternally in love with the eternal city.  Enjoy Rome...
!. walking around the center of rome is a magnificent experience! especially during the christmas holidays is beautifully decorated... be advised that during the weekends the place gets super crowed!
Stunning Roman Remains and classic buildings. The nain historical sites in Rome are mostly within easy walking distance. Bring good shoes and a map

stepping into the pages of history. surreal. breathtaking. incredible. words can't quite describe the feeling of walking around the ancient city of rome. it's as if one foot is in the past, and your other foot is in the present -- a roman aquaduct juts out of nowhere as you walk down a sidewalk, kids playing football on the grounds of a roman castle. amazing juxtapositions of old and new have made me realize why rome is indeed the eternal city.

Its like walking through a dream.. Its all there all those monuments you have seen countless times on TV. I soaked up the atmosphere and copied the locals, sitting on cafe terrasses and watching the world go by. You are essentially in a living museum with some of the greatest architecture in the world as a backdrop.

2400 years of history packed in a couple of miles. Colosseum, Roman Forum, Temple of Romulus, Senate Garden, Mussolini's Palace, Pallazzo Vittorio Emanuel, and the 7 hills of Rome, the Pantheon, St. Peter's Cathedral, have between them a territory that covers almost all the history of modern civilization.
History itsefl. Step by the Centro Storico makes you go back in time and wonder how was everything before. History was made in that spot. It´s so exciting!

Heart of Rome!. Dont take your map withyourself just go there and get lost!Than you will understand why Rome is memorable!in each minute you will discover new things and you will understand why the Rome were capital of Roman Empire!Bars,restaurants,small cafee shops it is just great!
The Best part of Rome. It is wonderful t owalk these streets very slowly and look up it is amazing what you will find!!!!The only place to stay too

The heart of the city..... To wander without destination......Bliss
I have done this manny times and each time it is a new experience. Many are the bars and restaurants we will never find again or will stumble across in years to come.
eternal city. city centre is full of wonderful sights and is so rich in history, you can keep on walking the cobbled streets and alleys and discover those beautiful piazzas and quaint cafe's

lost yourself. This is incredible little street all around that you seems to easily lost yourself but just do it ;-) it's impressive to walk along and discover all kind of colors and animation, all streets are different and all has its own charm

So much to see and so little time . . . .. I'm always amazed at how the sights in Rome are intermingled with the every day businesses. It's a very busy city; so crossing the street is not always the easiest.

Perfect Base. Centro storico was our home base for three weeks. Great market with friendly merchants at Campo de' Fiori. Lots of restaurants and cafe choices. Close to everything. We walked to the Vatican, to Villa Borghese, to Spanish steps, Trastevere, and of course all hpthe closer in sites and churches. Lots of buses and trams but we didn't have to use them, accept for a day trip.

You won't know where to look!. I had no idea what we'd stumble across in between the 'main,' attractions in rome and in all honesty I was completely amazed, I honestly didn't know where to look. My partner and I, kept nudging each other at the sites of different buildings, just viewing the architecture is a surreal experience.Luckily for us it was rather quiet around the centro storico we went so I really would recommend going early in the morning, as it is on its way to the colosseum and other busy attractions!

Going back in time. All the way down from the Colosseum to the piazza Vittorio Emmanuelle is just astonishing. The ancient forum, then across into the old town once you get past via Nazionale. Just a myriad of little winding streets with an eclectic mix of cafes and ice cream shops, and anything else which you'd expect to find in a cliche of Rome. But this is the real deal, and when you find a small cafe full of locals, you know you're onto a gem

Wander, Get Lost, Enjoy; Repeat. One of Rome's greatest treats is its ambiance. Sure, there are noisy scooters, crowded streets, and the ever-present fear of petty theft, but that's all part of the experience. (Well, I hope the petty theft part isn't part of your experience.) Wander the narrow streets, duck into a few churches where you can marvel at the art and rest your feet, enjoy the piazzas and their fountains, eat at a sidewalk cafe, and enjoy the experience.

outdoor museum. This is an absolutely amazing place.Orient yourself with the river and you won't get lost.Everything is old and important.Stop someplace any have a drink and slowly take in the sites.Keep your purses close to your body and try to be aware of people behind you as pickpockets are around.Don't let the pickpockets ruin your visit just be aware.

The whole centre is an endless museum!!!. You feel the history in every single place of Rome and you are astonished! Most of the places are ever so romantic but also are great inspirations of art. Otalina culture is ever so unique and it has been kept untouched in the historical centre. Food ouaou so yummy. Dont miss the gelato "Amarena" flavor.....it deserves the extra calories. It is the perfact balance of taste and excercise since you feel like you want to walk everywhere!
to see is to believe. amazing that these place was existed thousand years ago,i like foods ,especially pizza.I did not encounter any disappearance in my vacation in this lovely city

Felt in love over and over again. Simply wonderful time here... map is not necessary, it's easy walk, just take your time, walk slowly, you will get to enough historical sites, beautiful fountains, lively artists, busy cafes and delicious Gelatos...

nice place to get lost...only if you have time. The Rome Historic Centre is a very well preserved one and you can feel the history and the diversity all around you. You can walk very easy from an almost 2000 year old building to a Baroque Fountain. Anyway, be very careful in the cowded places cos there are a lot of thieves.
easy endless walking through history and culture. forget a map ... just walk ... you get unhurried history, food, drink, shopping at every turn and corner
Great to just wonder around and eat!. Great food, nice shops, lots fo churches and squares, lots to see and soak up the atmosphere especially at meal times

Where else?. The place to explore in Rome, especially if you are here for the first time. Also, it tends to be the place to go shopping (even just window-shopping) - be it along the via del Corso, or in the countless small streets all around it, crammed to the rafters with small, boutique shops. Great place to find restaurants and cafe's, as well as bars and random piazza-based outdoor drinking at night.Best approach to discovering the "real" Rome (OK, the upper-class, well off Rome): Find a couple of reference points (piazza Navona, Campo de Fiori, Panteon, etc) and then get lost in the alleys between them!
You don't have to spend $$ to enjoy!. just walk as much as you can, the whole city is a museum! I did everything that my Lonely Planet pocket book said is was for free and enjoyed my 2 day trip!
high quality cultural heritage. the remains of over 3.000 years of civilization are impressive, during the last decade well preserved and still broaden with new sites
Cool. Nice.Our hotel was i the center near Piazza Navone.Lots of people in the streets.Very good restaurants.The only problem are the millions of tourists...hehe

Amazing!. Truly amazing.
Art everywhere, in every corner, under every small pebble...
Just avoid the tourist traps and the crowds

Evening walk to Trevi Fountain. Loads of people and junky tourist shops but nothing can distract from the beauty of Rome on a warm evening. The ancient streets and pastel coloured palaces took on a new beauty at night.

You can't miss it. Go to Rome and don't go to Centro Storico??? No way. It is THE reason to go to Rome. So many things to see. Very impressive. To many things to see, I can't tell you just in few words. Take a book and see. You will be convinced. Story, story, story. And Rome keep all this in a relative good condition. A must in a live.

One of world's best places. Rome's historical centre is amazing. I truly love simply walking through the cobblestone streets, getting lost, and soaking in the history and culture. Check out any church you come across. They are beautiful places to pray. So much history, so much beauty, so much culture. Eat some gelato as you walk!

Every turn.......... Just loved this area. There's so much to see.Every corner you turn there's an amazing sight. So much history.The only downside for me was the number of beggars and homeless people. More than I've seen anywhere else in European cities.

great views but too busy. I felt like I was at the notting hill carnival - the amount of people in the area was immense and to be honest ruined it! I had been to Rome 10 years earlier (in March) and I don't remember having to battle for space. We couldn't see most of the sights because of the crowds!
Great area with nice shops and delis. One of the most beautiful areas in Rome. It's very original and unpretential. Good place to have a capuccino and watch people passing by.

Impressive! Illuminating!. The Center of Rome made up of the Colosseum, the Foro Romano and the Palatino/Circo Massimo is by far one of the most impressive sites I have had a chance to see. It gave me an historical perspective that can only be given by being there. Makes Paris outright modern and puts many sites e.g., the Chartres Cathedral and even Christian and Moslem history and beliefs into the light of an historical perspective that for me was almost schocking! Rome had over a million people over 2000 years ago! Glad I came!

The Coliseum - A life time visit. Rome is an open museum. I would say that you should not miss the Coliseum and the Forum. Piazza Novana is amazing - specially at night. I am very critical of things I visit. But there is nothing to be criticized about Rome. Oh yes. One thing though. And hopefully the Roman authorities will read this. Bottles of water in the tourist area are too expensive. 2-4 Euros for a bottle of 50CL is way to much. Just imagine you are a family of 5 and you stay the whole day outside and have to drink a minimum of 1,5L per person, it will cost you just in water for the whole day: 30 Euros - and when it is too hot like in the summer, you might have to double or triple that amount. Here the authorities should do something. Either build fountains, like in the USA, or democratize the price of the water. In the meantime, my advise is: take lots of water from the Supermarket with you. Just a bottle of 50cl can cost no more than 13 cents if you get it a the right place. That is, if you visit Rome during a very hot summer and you drink about 3l in a day for a family of 5, it will cost you only: 1,95 Euros.

Take a tour and jump the queue. For 25 euros you get a tour guide for the forum nd the coloseum(12 euros without) and you jump the queue, which can be up to 2 hours. It is also the quickest way to learn the facts.
The heart of Rome. This is the Rome of history and of films. It is what I came to see and experience. Even tho certain spots are mobbed with tourists, this truly the wonderful heart of Rome.
You can´t see it all. There is so much in the historic center of Rome, you just can´t see it all. So, just choose some of it and walk and enjoy the unique atmosphere of the city.
Very charming and great atmosphere. I couldn't help but fall in love with Roma - all the little cobblestone lanes and piazzas with gourgeous water fountains...Loved it!

Centro storico. i took a guided tour by Colosseo, Palatino and Forum. it was really interesing to walk in so old places. I was particularly impressed with Colloseo. It must have been a magnificent building
beautiful rome!. you can't say that you have seen Rome if you haven't walked in its beautiful historic center!just take some time for a walk and enjoy it!
Don't miss the old town.. Very nice neighborhood. Old buildings, restaurants, and shops. Don't miss it. It's certainly worth a walk.

The heart of Rome. We're a little biased: this is where our home is. But this is also the literal heart of Rome, both ancient and modern. The Centro Storico includes, among other things, the Republican-era Forum Boarium; the Imperial-era Roman and Imperial Forums and the Colosseum; the Baroque splendor of the Spanish Steps and the Trevi Fountain; and the many magnificent piazzas that are this incredible city. One tip: don't overbook your time here. Leave time to stroll and get lost, to grab a coffee or a drink at some little place, and watch the world go by. Get off the beaten path and wander and discover something wonderful. For example, if you happen to walk along Via del Pie’ di Marmo (marble foot street), you will find, sitting on a pedestal, a giant marble foot from an ancient Roman statue. That's the beauty of Rome, the Eternal City.
Good to visit. Not much of an architecture. Must be visited on foot. Stock to Monti, gheto and Trastevere to get a feel of the past. Do not miss the Roman Ruins.
Beautiful' beautiful Rome. Instead, you enjoy just walking around the streets, enjoy the special atmosphere and romantic. You come back here again and again

Must see. Everything is so close together. Easy walking distance to all the historical attractions. Great places to eat. Definitely rent an apartment. DO NOT rent a car! Impossible to drive in Rome! Don not take a cab from the airport. Hire a driver to take you from the airport to your hotel/apartment and back to the airport again.
So much to see!. Impressive sights every step of the way but, they should improve the transportation system. The buses are extremely crowded and the metro stations far away from one another.

Fabulous!. Soaking up the history on every step, walking down the narrow streets, enjoying the sunshine and shadows were a dream. We've been here many times but never tire of all the hidden areas and details.
In your face history. Such a surprising place for someone from the New World. Everywhere you look, there's more and more - all within easy walking distances.

There is only one Rome!. It looks dilapidated sometimes; it is not picture perfect, but it has a feeling like no other city. Almost everywhere you turn you are faced by remnants - many monumental, others mere stones - of its history.

Stay here and walk to everything!. We stayed at the Relais Maddalena in the heart of Centro Rome just steps from the Pantheon. This is truly the best way to experience the city as we walked to all the major attractions, as well as drifted through the ancient wandering streets and just soaked up being in Rome. Wandering through this area led to some great finds...quaint shopping area open late at night filled with true Romans (and shoe shops galore!), restaurants filled with locals, pockets of ancient ruins surrounded by high fashion, and more gelato than can be possibly eaten in one lifetime. Centro Storico is not to be missed.
Centro Storico always lively!. The "old town" area of Rome is alive with great restaurants, coffee shops, and historic sites to visit. We never get tired of this beautiful area.
Unique. Feeds the soul..too much to take in in one visit..keep coming back to Rome to discover more of its history
Glad we werent driving!. Very clean and easy to get around. You can't hail a taxi which we didn't know until late one night. Felt very safe.

The Centre of Rome. Every which way you turn, every side street you look down and every piazza you you stumble across will never cease to amaze you. We only visited for 4 days and yet we could probably have spent 4 months in Rome and still not have seen every thing. The culture the food and the sites where every thing we expected and more. Only one bit of advise, take plenty of Euros!

Beauty abounds--history lives. It's a given, even in October, that Rome is swarming with tourists. Nevertheless the beauty everywhere you look, the great historical connections and the people make it one of the top great cities of the world

Ruins are great, people are sooo mean.... It was a great experience to see front row the Centro Storico, but once is enough for me. People are so rude, as if they did not like tourists at all. Not helpful and do not even lose your time asking for ANY instructions/directions, they will yell at you. I can count only three people that were kind enough to help. We bought the Roma Pass and it seems that the bar code was damage and did not read well. Every time we tried to use it we had problems. NO employee from the Metro took the time to check on it. They kept yelling at us that we were not sliding the card correctly. Until finally an employee from the Roman Forum figure out what was the problem. Everything looks so dirty and not taken care of. I rather see the ruins and Rome on TV than to ever go back!!

Perfect private tour. We love the tour of the Dark Rome Agency specially because of the guide Valentina, intelligent, kind, efficient and happy! Few people, excellent audio system and good choice of attractions!we bought the tour in local rome tours site
lovely for a wander. You pass through a lot of this between historic sites and general wandering, lovely area could have spent longer here without hubby and children!
A walk among the ruins. Great place to visit and see historic Rome. The guides and descriptions are comprehensive. Not many tourists and the tickets are cheap.

Beautiful. Loved it. The center is filled with ruins, from the colisseum to the Forum. Beautifull buildings in Victorino Emanuele square. Everywere there are small water points were you can refill your water bottles.

Phenomenal. Right in the middle of a major metropolitan city, you find yourself standing on either side of a wide modern road, looking at the 2000+ year old ruins below your feet and seeing an ancient city take shape around you. Raise your head and you're struck by the sight of ancient catacombs and arches and monuments in all directions; excited now that you can see it's not just a bunch of rubble but a city within a city, you ride the elevator up the "birthday cake" (Il Vittoriano) and get a birds-eye view; then back down and stroll up the road, taking it all in, only to find yourself at the colosseum! And you're blown away yet again. This place should be seen at least once by every living breathing human being.
Always surprising!. It may be crowded and noisy but is one of the more fascinating cities in the world. The Roman Empire, the Renaissance , the Manierism and Barroque in a few blocks.

Take a Long Walk. Just take a long and random walk through the centre of the city. There are the usual tourist attractions, but it's the serendipity of finding interesting things that makes this worthwhile. This is one of the areas that makes Rome feel so lovely and enriching to visitors.

Skip the lines at Colosseum. Is great if you avoid lines. But ticket at Forum or Palatino, OR get the Roma Pass, OR reserve online, OR mention that you will go for the audiotour (they have a special line for this), and they will let you go through the special line that will take you to the group line and you can purchase the audiotour with your ticket
One of the most important world heritage. One of the most important world heritage, in some little and short street it seems to be 1000 years before, where the time has stopped: timeless places.
Centro Storico. Truly charming and amazing historical area. So much to absorb and something different around each corner.

Awesome!. Rome's historical centre is everything I expected. One of the greatest places on Earth for those interested in history, architecture, engineering, art and civilisation. An awesome place, in the true sense of the word.

The absolute real heart of Rome. This is the second visit to Rome and we have stayed in Centro Storico both times and fell in love with it all over again. You can wander all the little cobbled laneways and then come out into the most wonderful piazzas. Walking to most all of the important sites(& some hidden gems also) is so easy. Cross the Ponto Sisto to the beautiful Trastavere, wander to the Ghetto, stroll the via Giulia up to Castel Santangelo and then across to St Peters square with very little effort.
centro storico- city centre. i loved the centro.. the colosseum and the roman forum were breathtaking... a took a lot of photos.. LOVED IT!!!

The best part of Rome. Centro Storico is the most beautiful part of Rome. The atmosphere is amazing and you can find a lot of restaurants, shops and ice cream shops here. It's perfect for an afternoon stroll.
Wow. Beautiful, and not as busy as I expected. Also the small scale makes it easily walkable, even in the hottest weather
wonderful. Walking through the old town we loved, Rome is a beautiful city, full of wonderful history and the Italians are very nice and sociable.

Love this city. we fell in love with this city.Spent 5 nights last summr and returned this year. Night walk from P Navonna, Pantheon,Trevi Fountain! A must return again!Take the time to visit all the littel chrurches, packed with art

Fantastic!!. I like that you can visit easily in two days cause everything is in a walk distance: One day from Fontana di Trevi - via Pantheon and Piazza Navona to Campo di Fiore and a second day from Piazza Venezia to Piazza di Spanha ( crossing and maybe shopping at via del Corso) . There are several monuments and churches in both paths if you have more time and it has plenty of bars, restaurants and nice "gelaterias"- ice crem shops everywhere. It is save for a woman to walk alone even in the evening .I long to visit again soon.
Always amazing!. You will find it easy to hire a tour service/guide. It is well worth it to skip the lines at places like the Coliseum.

Mindboggling. Not sure how to distill our feelings into a short review. Just about every ten steps you run into a historical site worth at least a few minutes of reading in a guide book. We walked around with a constant state of awe and never tired of noting the ancient provenance of a particular building or archaelogical remnant.

Centro Storico is a must see. The Colosseum, Palatine, Constantine's Arch and the Forum. Its a wonder to see. If you can afford it get a private tour guide, (around E150 for 3 hours) he will get you the tickets before hand so you don't wait in line anywhere. Also they know their history and it makes it that much more interesting. You can't miss this.

Amazing. Roma Pass costs E30 (available all over the city and station) gives you 3 days bus/metro travel and avoids queuing for tickets. We visited in the order: Colisseum, Palatino, Forum. You do not need a guide if you do some research beforehand. Toilets and water fountains at each site. Start with the Colisseum museum to get an idea of what you are about to see (even better start by going to the top of the Vittorio Emanuele memorial and look down on the centro storico without paying). The Palatino "Hill" barely counts as a hill for most people but trainers are better than open toed sandals as it is dusty and stoney. You do need a good imagination to interpret what you are looking at. It does not really compare to Hadrian's villa at Tivoli (which he prefered to his palace at Palatino).

Absolutelly unique. Rome has character and charm which is absolutelly unique. A walk by the city center is a wonderful experience that evoques its history from Tarteses, through the ancient times of Roman Empire, Renaissance and La Dolce Vita years. Absolutelly recommended.

Rome's heartbeat. If you are ready to walk and willing to feel the pulse of the "Eternal City', then this is your chance. It is a maze of narrow streets where people live next to some amazing monuments like the Trevi Fountain, Hadrian Wall, the Pantheon and as far as Piazza Navona. There are charming cafés and restaurants, small shops, wine bars and an array of interesting shop windows. One of them sells wooden toys among which the famed Pinocchio! This is a UNESCO site and it is really worth walking it through and through to discover more hidden treasures.
a wonderful wander. everywhere you look the ancient and modern history of Rome surrounds you: from Romans to modern Italian design. Excellent and walkable everywhere.
Beautiful. Breathtaking.. If you have just one day in rome, this is where you go. But make sure that you're with one of the What A Life tour guides to make you appreciate the ruins further.

All the sights within walking distance. Walked from hotel to Trevi Fountain, through the narrow streets passed the Hadrian temple ruins, the Pantheon, Piazza della Minerva, Santa Maria Sopra Minerva, il Gesú, Area Sacra, Piazza dei Fiori, Piazza Navona, San Luigi dei Francesi, Piazza La Rotunda, Collonna, Corsa, Spanish Steps, Villa Borghese, Via Veneto. 5 hours with breaks and lunch. Brilliant!

The City of Endless Surprises!. Rome is full of history and great architecture. You can walk and always find something beautiful to admire. It is an amazing city that is full of surprises, for example an actual pyramid in Rome. Wow! You can go to the same place over and over again, and always see something different. I truly loved exploring the subway trains and buses. It was quite the experience, but the people are quite friendly and help you get around. Can't wait to go again.

Packed with atmosphere.. Lovely, you discover something new wherever you go. Great for just wondering around and enjoying a plunge into history. It is almost all restricted traffic area, it is clean and you feel safe.

A MUST VISIT. There is so much history in here. We hired a private guide for the trip inside, and wow. You live and you learn so much. We bought the tickets online in advance, and printed them at home. Since we had pre purchased ticket and a guide we were able to walk right in and skip the line that almost seemed endless. Once inside the guide explained everything from history to architecture. How it was and how it is. Why there are holes in the wall. How this was rebuilt and why. Definitely a must do. You can spend a couple of hours easily. They also have an underground tour that we unfortunately did not get to do this time around.
fascinating walk through history. You can walk through the history books and it all comes to life. Just wonderful - though probably best to avoid the heat and crowds and go in spring or autumn

History in front of you at every turn. For an American, history is in a few hunderd years...our time in Centro Storico was truly history and something not soon forgotten. I think it is awesome that archeological digs are more and more active and that protecting the ruins is a priority. We were there in the early and late evening and the quieter it got, the more inspiring it became. Genius without computers was everywhere in the construction and design.

When in Rome. Sorry, I had to make the bad pun for the title. Definitely a must if your in Rome. Reasonable price and if you can catch it either early in the day or at the end it won't be as crowded. Truly an extraordinary experience seeing the stairs now dissolved by time. The under workings of the coliseum were also fascinating. It is very close in proximity to the Roman Forum another must on your sightseeing list. Neither of them are new and innovative attractions but there's a reason that people travel across the world to lay their eyes on this site, endless history and every time you watch the Gladiator with your friends you may feel like a bad..., lol. If this was helpful let me know, thanks and great travels, Dante R.

Still amazes me after 16 years. I have lived in Rome for 16 Years and live in the area of Trastevevere. i'm very lucky. This city is just amazing. I have travelled alot but always pleased to come back home. It is like an open air museum.
Amazing heritage centre. Like no where else in the world. Much better than expected - no problems with pick pockets unlike the warnings, and everything easy to get to. Plus great cafes!

Get lost in ancient Rome. August is probably not the best month (too hot, too many tourist and be alert for pickpocketing, particularly when taking the bus or underground), but nevertheless worthwhile more than one trip to Rome. Take the "side-streets" away from major Plazas to share a typical restaurant outside the stream of tourists. Avoid expensive (abusive?) restaurants at Piazza Navona. Cheapest beverage: mineral water (0,75-1 liter) is the cheapest. Coke or similar range from 3 to 4.- Euro!!!
Very alive. You can never miss this! People from allover the world in perfect harmony. Get a map and enjoy your time!

Takes your breath away. We visited the coloseum and the roman forum in August. It is extremely hot at this time of year and most romans take off to the seaside and countryside to escape the heat. If you are going to Rome over the summer months I would advise visiitng the centro storico early in the morning to avoid the intense heat as there is no shade or cover to escape the sun. It's also amazing when lit up late at night and they've started to sell tickets for nightitme visits but you need to book these in advance.We bought a Roma Pass which gives you unlimited travel on the metro, buses and trams and free entry into yout first two museums or attractions, The coloseum and roman forum count as one entry.  The coloseum literally took my breath away with it's magnificence, it is just an amazing feat of architecture and amazing that the model is still used today when building modern stadia. The Roman forum is also a must see. Augustus's palace with its mosaics still intact, the curia where the senate sat to the various temples, vesta, saturn etc., will produce goose bumps. You can hire a hand held guide from the ticket booth but will have to leave your passports until you return them or canu se a good guide book.Allow a couple of hours at least to see both the colosseum and the forum.
Wonderful world!. A labyrinth of streets with amazing sights around every corner. An area that will stay in the mind for ever.

Amazing Monuments - how to miss Colosseum queues + helpful Tourist info. We were in Rome this week and it was amazing- temerature was around 30 C, and last week of August, so this is the 'quiet season', but it was busy with tourist groups from all around the world. Centro Storico has so many monuments to see - but if you get confused, then take advantage of the many tourist information booths in the city. They have multilingual staff and will provde free maps which list all the key attractions. These maps were also available in our hotel and as you wander through the city you will see many tourists using the maps to guide them.When we went to the Colosseum the lines were of course long, so we walked the 10 minutes to the Palatine ticket booth, queued there for 20 minutes to buy our tickets - and when we went into the Colosseum we were glad we had bought the tickets as the lines to get in, are a long way into the building itself ! Note that for EU citizens under 18 entry is free - you may be asked for ID at the ticket booth so we took our passports long. For 18-24 the price for Colosseum was 7.5 Euros.We found that around 90 minutes was enough to see the Colosseum (we did not have a guide, used a guide book instead)
Palatine Hill and Forum. Awesome to be walking in the steps of the Caesars! Colosseum was breathtaking and so complex in design, it is hard to believe it is 2000 years old

Like stepping back into time. Lots of exciting historical icons to see, all within easy walking distance. Piazza Navona has fountains, a church, restaurants, and lots of artists. The Forum & Palatine Hill ruins are interesting. Sit & imagine Caesar & his chariot is passing. The Colosseum and surrounding arches are impressive. The Pantheon is breathtaking with its dome and tomb of Rafael. Nearby is the Trevi fountain & the Spanish Steps - all good photographic opportunities. Wear proper walking shoes, as I fractured my foot with all the walking I did.
Rome, la bella Vita. How can you not love Rome. The historic buildings, the fountains, the people, the food, the life. What more is there to say?

Must do!. You can not come to Rome and not visit the Forum. You now have to enter the Forum from down near the Colosseum and pay. We came in 2005 when much of it was closed but the central walkway was open and free. It is easy to miss things. The museum overlooking the Circo Massimo was interesting. Take your time and soak up the atmosphere, letting your imagination join in. There are plenty of 'Aqua Roma' points - free flowing drinking water. We visited on a hot sunny day and everyone was drinking gallons! The main point of buying bottled water is to buy the bottle - which you refill again and again. These drinking points are scattered all around the old part of Rome.

Old and interesting neighborhood in Rome. We felt fortunate that our hotel was located in Centro Storico, the heart of Rome. Lots of really old streets and convenient to many of the major attractions of Rome. Our hotel was located in a quieter section of Centro Storico near the river: narrow, old, cobblestone streets, lots of interesting picturesque buildings, and some good restaurants off the tourist path. Lots of history and easy to get to everything - I would highly recommend staying in this area if coming to Rome.

"VERY VERY GOOD". Highly recommended to anyone visiting Rome,an area where you can find ancient buildings, beatiful fountains, columns, obelisks, masterpieces, museums, piazzas, such high concentration of churchs and religious places, all combined with centennial buildings.
You will go in any case. It is a nice walk and gives you a real good idea about how it was Rome in the old days. Unfortunately some of the buildings and monuments are not in good shape.

The most interesting historical area to 'rome' around!. This is actually the best area to roam any time of the day. No matter which way you turn, you'll come across fantastic detailed architectural buildings with statues and main focal points in pretty squares with quaint narrow streets and busy market areas. Its packed with lots of eating establishments with outdoor seating and is very romantic. A step back in time and much nicer than the modern areas of Rome. This is the place to form your base from which to explore all the main historical sites.
its a must. its just stunning , walking arround in so much history. Its important that you get out to the attractions early. Can easly get long waiting lines

The heart of the Eternal City. Probably there is not other place like that in the entire world, an area in which you can find ancient buildings, beatiful fountains, columns, obelisks, masterpieces, museums, piazzas, such high concentration of churchs and religious places, all combined with centennial buildings in which Romans and tourists share a XXI century lifestyle. The Centro Storico is a terrific fusion of the Italian culture that summarizes more than 2000 years of history in a few square kilometers: Great examples of ancient, Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque, Neoclassic and modern buildings can be found here. The area concentrates more attractions than any other place in the entire Europe: the Colosseum, the Roman Forum, the Palatine, Piazza Spagna, the Pantheon, Fontana di Trevi and the Arch of Constantine are only a few examples.
VERY GOOD. A graphic location to please any visitor. Highly recommended to anyone visiting Rome. Ensure your camera is with you
Incredible History. This area of Rome is where all the ancient sites are, plus incredible Church's with Art by the greatest Artists on earth.
JUST BEAUTIFUL. Beautiful Piazza after beautiful piazza. Amazing history around every corner. You can just sit and soak up the atmosphere, or visit a breathtaking church, or artefact.

Old Rome? Get lost and it gets even better.. Fabulous architecture, restaurants & hotels make the Centro Storico (historic, old center of Rome) our favorite part of the best city in Europe. You cannot call your visit complete without a visit to fontana di Trevi, and to the left of the Pantheon, the restaurant La Segrestia on Via Seminario, the famous gelateria, Giolitti. the coffee shop *Sant Eustachio – Il Caffé: go past the right side of the Pantheon, and turn right. Other must sees: Piazza Navona, Buyr Pizza Bianca at the Forno (bakery) in Campo de Fuori. Get lost, and it gets even better.

History on every corner. Rome is a fabulous city full of some of the world's most famous sites. My 12-year old loved it and was fascinated by the history. This is a "must-see" city for everyone of all ages.
Always charming. Rome is a charming city which has a lot to offer; from historical sites to religon; museums; parcs, shopping, nice trattoria's, ... an not to forget ... ice creams

simply the top. Rome has the largest historical centre in Europe and you get crazy before sayng you saw all of its attractions. The good is also the number of old and attracting shops, the bars the restaurant to seat outside and enjoy the people walking and chatting all the time... wonderful

Incredible. Not much to say about this area that hasn't already been said. Beautiful monuments everywhere, incredible things to see! Just walk around and get lost, you can go on for days and days! Must see!

Exhausting but worth it. When you arrive in Rome for the first time, it is a bit difficult to orient yourself and to decide which monument to visit first. We decided to start with the visit of the Vatican (Museum, garden and Saint Peter cathedral). What saved our day was that we took a walking tour which allowed us to avoid the longue lines at the entrance (3 hours queuing, no thanks). From there we walked through the Trastevere and came back to our hotel near the Trevi fountain. You could call that a day! Do as the Romans did--Walk It!. It’s very important to experience Rome by foot. I realize that the city can be exhausting with so many museums, churches & ruins to visit; however, you'll be missing the spirit of Rome if you don’t walk the streets. Most major landmarks are connected by very simple & scenic streets that run parallel to the major, traffic-ridden streets. Don’t be afraid to take these streets. They offer many surprises & treats.VIA ALESSANDRINA. If you are walking between the Coliseum/Forum & the Victor Emmanuel II Monument, please take the time to walk on Via Alessandrina, which runs parallel to the Via dei Fori Imperiali—the main street leading to/from the Coliseum/Forum. Via Alessandrina begins by Trajan’s Column and runs beside Trajan’s Market before merging back into Via dei Fori Imperiali. You won’t get lost by using Via Alessandrina since Via dei Fori Imperiali is visible from Alessandrina. Plus, Via Alessandrina is mostly a pedestrian street, so you’ll have a little break from the crazy traffic. A stop at Trajan’s Column is worth your time. The relief carvings on the column are the deepest, sharpest & most impressively designed in Rome. It’s elaborate & beautiful—not only a testament to Emperor Trajan’s power but also to his craftsmen that designed & executed the column. At the base of Trajan’s Column is an excavated area with column stumps & ruins, which you can’t see from Via dei Fori Imperiali, so get up close to the column. Behind the column is the church Santa Marie di Loreto, which could provide a cool refuge in the summer heat. Its octagonal floor plan under a wide dome is calming & peaceful. Along Via Alessandrina, you’ll see the Trajan Market, which is very impressive in height, scale & design. You can walk down into the ruins a little by the side of the street & see some nice tile work.VIA DEL TEATRO MARCELLO. If you are visiting the Capitoline Museum, start at the front of the Victor Emmanuel II Monument and walk Via del Teatro Marcello to the base of the Capitoline Hill. You will pass a neglected but strong Roman ruin, the Insula Romana Ara Coeli, which is an apartment building from 200 A.D. The ancient apartments are overshadowed by the side of the Victor Emmanuel II Monument and largely forgotten. It’s just standing there, ignored. But it’s a fascinating ruin, and as the building’s ground floor is far below the current street level, one can imagine that the apartments must have been ancient Rome’s proud skyscrapers at one point. If you look closely, you’ll find an ancient fresco of Jesus’ last supper (I think), by one of the building’s windows. It’s still amazingly well defined & fresh. It's too bad that many tourists don’t walk this route. You shouldn’t miss this! And when you pass the Romana Ara Coeli, you’ll be at the base of Michelangelo’s grand staircase entry into the Capitoline Hill. This is the intended entry to the hill & museum, and therefore the best route to take. VIA CORONARI. After visiting Piazza Navonna, if you're headed to the Ponte Sant’Angelo to either access Castel Sant’Angelo or the Vatican, then take Coronari Street. Between these megastar landmarks is this medieval lane. It’s a beautiful experience. You can access Via Coronari directly at the end of Piazza Navonna, where four streets intersect at the Piazza Tor Sanguigna. One of the intersecting streets is the start of Coronari Street. Also at this intersection, there is a hole that exposes an entombed ancient level beneath the foundations of one building. If one leans into the hole, the remains materialize of Emperor Domitian’s Stadium, constructed in 86 A.D. One of the stadium’s terrace arches is viewable & astonishingly preserved. When you pass the stadium ruins, head onto the cobblestoned Coronari Street; it’s the small street, the one that is no wider than the shoulders of five large men standing side to side. Coronari was part of Pope Sixtus IV’s urban renewal project in the early 1400s, along with the Sistine Chapel. Its peak traffic was during the late Middle Ages, when pilgrims used the street to walk towards the Vatican. Knowing the pilgrims’ path, merchants lined the route with rosaries for sale; so, the street became called Via dei Coronari since rosary beads were referred to as crowns of beads—coronari. On the street, you’ll find building shrines & many antique shops. Even if you don't care to shop, here you can absorb a classic Roman spirit. Coronari buildings exude Italian shabby-chic—peeling plasters of earth-colors, predominately parched browns & bleached oranges. The doorways are tight, often lined with white marble. There are climbing plants on the walls & charming shuttered windows. This is the Rome that many of us imagine prior to visiting. Coronari will end on the street that becomes Ponte Sant’Angelo, so you will not get lost on this street. VIA DEI PASTINI / VIA DELLE MURATTE. If you are traveling between the Pantheon & Trevi Fountain, take Via dei Pastini which is called Via delle Muratte once you pass the major street, Via del Corso. You’ll pass a lot of buildings with corner shrines & also pass the side of the Italian Stock Exchange which incorporated the ancient and COLOSSAL columns from the Temple of Hadrian, which used to stand here. The temple columns are very impressive! Along this route you’ll also find a mix of specialty arts & craft shops as well as tacky touristy souvenir shops. So if you’re looking to buy souvenirs—ranging from unique art to funny kitschy, this is the street. When the street becomes Via delle Muratte on the other side of Via del Corso, it becomes a pedestrian street--no cars. The shopping also becomes livelier & tackier. There are long rows of market stalls here with paper souvenirs—postcards, posters, etc. Sometimes street performers provide entertainment on the Via delle Muratte part of the road, closer to the Trevi Fountain. At the end of Via delle Muratte, you’ll be facing the Trevi Fountain. Very fun street!

Walking in the Historic District. Centro Storico in Rome,,, is like being in a time machine..., a good guide book is invaluable ( i.e. The Companion Guide to Rome- Masson) ..... but simply walking around Centro Storico ,,, Historic District .... with eyes open... you will find untold surprises.... Roman Columns here... old steps there.... an ancient church full of world class artwork.. the lava cobblestoned streets.... old fountains... Walking around this area is like being in a "living museum "...... The Pantheon..... no mater how many times you visit this.... Hadrian's Temple to all God's... is always a special stop.. ( try to go early a.m. ... to avoid the massive summer crowds) ... A map ( and guide book) are helpful.. but sometimes just strolling around,,, getting "lost".... can make for a very unique and special time.... ( one suggestion... for your visit,, try to reserve your hotel within the Centro Storico area....so as to be in the heart of the Ancient City) as you will then be within walking distance to most of the sights that you will want to see.

Navigated it with my Ipad and 2 kids..... Rome has some amazing history. It's fun to imagine what it must have been like when Rome first started. Oh the history!Fast forward a few thousand years and it's amazing how far we've come. This was the first time I navigated Rome with an Ipad and how helpful it was with Google Maps on the Ipad. Even with no data plan, we didn't have ANY problems at all always getting the map up on the Ipad. It's great going through all the ancient streets. It's fun to purposely get lost on some of these small streets.Although there are TONS of tourists during the summer, it's still fairly easy to navigate and there are many crosswalks and almost all have signals and those that don't the traffic is good about yielding to pedestrians which is nice.We had 2 strollers with our young kids and we easily made it around with crowds being good when they see you with kids.

Centro Storico with children. Visited with 3 children (10,12,14) on a very hot day so found the plentiful water fountains more than useful! All loved the colosseum but the children really didn't see the point of visiting the Palatine. It rather disappointed us too; it's not that the buildings are in such a poor ruined state (although they are!) but that there are very few explanations of what you are looking at and almost no pictures to help children visualise what was there. Even with the 'Rome Reconstructed' book in hand (very good) it was difficult to imagine the historical reality from the actual sights before us. The Forum was better for them so we would advise to do the Colosseum 1st, the Forum 2nd and the Palatine last (treating it mostly like a lovely walk so it can't disappoint.)It was difficult to know how to work out the benefits of the Roma Pass with the children because there does not seem to be sufficient information readily available online re discounts and travel costs etc. In the end we bought here in Rome 2 Roma Passes for us (now 30E) and have got the children in to all the 'antiquity' sites for free (EU passport holders only.) We found that the cost of transport is low generally so we have saved money by not buying the pass for them. The passes were great though because we were all able to bypass the very long Colosseum queue and go straight in. A real blessing at 27C!

The shopping is only interrupted by the beauty of the Roman sites that you visit upon naturally. Rome is one of the few cities in the world where you can happen upon the ancient, th
Amazing!. Every street is a surprise. Get lost in small ones, and you will find amazing places!

Best city center in the world for on foot sightseeing. Rome has so many wonderful treasures packed into a relatively small city center. You can easily walk from one thing to the next, and see loads of things along the way. I can't think of a better city to lose yourself in. Churches are free to enter (just don't disturb during the Masses) and contain wonderful works of art by Berini, Caravaggio and Michelangelo. There are fountains - both of the wildly decorative and the functional kind. You can drink out of any of the upright running fountains you see in the neighborhoods. Put your finger on the bottom of the spout and the water will curve out like a fountain from a hole at the top of the spout. Rome is full of busy tourist areas, large green expanses of park and quite, romantic piazzas. My favorite city in the world.
Real Rome. Just wandering round the streets transports you back to renaissance Rome. Rome is not just about the major monuments, churches and galleries. Make time to "waste" time

Each time you go out, you will find something new. I recently visited Rome for 14 days, and walked everywhere....each time you go out, you discover some hidden gem. Put the map away and just wander and explore, you can't really get lost in Rome. You will find some fabulous little eatery for lunch, that isn't in the tour guide, or some lovely little bar for a leisurely coffee. The point is...take the time and smell the roses..and enjoy Rome. Isn't that the point of coming here in the first place?

you want to walk around all day. The centre of Rome has all so many historic monuments and buildings that you want to walk around all day,for many days and you don't have seen enough.

best stroll in Rome. just walk, no map, lose yourself in the narrow streets. Don't worry, you can always ask direction or reach a place that you are familiar with. You will 'discover' much more than on a planned route.
Unique!. Not a patch on Margate! A fantastic experience. What a city, we'll be back in the summer :-)
Just a pleasure to visit .. It is amazing to be able to walk around all those ruins and imagine the life so many years ago ,and sooo much history happening there...

You have to visit to historical centre of Rome.. Rome can seem sprawling and difficult but the historical centre can be walked easily on foot with a good map. Essential places are Piazza Navona with its fountains, the Pantheon, the church of the Gesu and the Trevi Fountain which are unique to this city. Rome is the most historic city in the world with many layers of history superimposed in the spaces and buildings.

Great place to meander. The historic heart of ancient Rome is a great place to meander at your leisure and to absorb and to admire the fountains and buildings and perhaps to stop off for a coffee at Tazo or a gelato along the way. Crowds can be large day or night but go with the flow.

Dark alleys and lovely piazzas. The dark narrow streets are easy to get lost in. But around the corner there is always a piazza, often with a church that has fantastic examples of baroque art. Do not miss the ghetto and the synagogue!

Proper Rome. Great area to go "people watching" Lovely old buildings, hidden shops, restaurants. Easy to get lost.
Beautiful area. We had our hotel in the centro storico- what else could we ask for? All the main piazzas and highlights within a stone's throw away. Beautiful areas, statues, fountains

Do not miss. Every corner is breath taking. Beautiful mixture of new and ancient. The experience is awesome!
Let yourself be taken away from your reality. Enter is this time travelling machine.
